Fred Smith and Sons also has several 18- and 26-tonne Axor rigids in its fleet with another 18-tonner due to be delivered soon. The vehicles are fitted with the firm’s own bodies, but Smith emphasises that sales service, parts and warranty back-up are all ‘first class’.

item.title: First Actros Titan put to work at Hampshire construction plant
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
According to a report in The Construction Index, the UK’s first Mercedes-Benz Actros Titan heavy haulage unit is to be put to work at a construction plant in Hampshire. The Mercedes Actros truck, which has a brand new transmission type along with a new and improved MegaSpace cab, is to be used by the Fareham-based operator Chappell’s of Stubbington. It will be put to work transporting plant and machinery on behalf of businesses working within the demolition and construction sector. As well as being capable of shifting weights of up to 150 tonnes, the Actros Titan 4160S also boasts Aa600hp, 16-litre V8 engine and a Mercedes PowerShift automated gearbox. It also has the new Voith VIAB Turbo Clutch, which features a built-in retarder for additional braking. As no external retarder is needed, this small, integrated clutch frees up chassis space and boosts payload capacity. Commenting on his firm’s new acquisition, the director of Chappell’s, Mark Harris, said:
“The automated PowerShift transmission with Turbo Clutch is superb, and gives us the best of both worlds. When pulling away and working at low speeds the Turbo Clutch is extremely sensitive and makes the truck very easy to manoeuvre."

item.title: Winter maintenance advice for commercial fleet managers
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
With winter just around the corner, now is the time for fleet managers to ensure that each and every one of their Mercedes trucks, vans and others vehicles are fully prepared for the onset of cold weather and poor driving conditions.
The following tips should help you to prepare your fleet for winter:
•Carry out a full servicing check on all vehicles, checking everything from functionality of lights and wear on brake pads to tread depth on tyres and condition of windscreen wipers.
•Ensure the batteries on all your Mercedes trucks are fully charged
•Give drivers enough anti-freeze and windscreen washer to top up regularly
•Improve or upgrade communication and vehicle tracking systems, just in case a driver breaks down or gets in trouble in an isolated area during bad weather
•Train your fleet drivers in safe winter driving habits. Advice to impart includes braking and manoeuvring advice on icy roads and what to keep in the vehicle in case of emergency.
It’s important not to leave it until winter actually arrives to prepare your fleet for winter. Act now, before one of your Mercedes vans or trucks ends up stranded in the snow.

item.title: FTA warns of potential CPC driver training shortage
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
According to a recent report, the Freight Transport Association (FTA) has warned that drivers leaving vital training to the last minute could lead to a shortage of adequately trained drivers by the Driver CPC deadline. By September 2014, a deadline less than two years away, all truck and lorry drivers must have completed a total of 35 hours of training and have received a Driver Certificate of Professional Competence (CPC). However, the FTA is concerned that the industry is not treating the deadline with enough urgency, resulting in fewer drivers than required undertaking the training. The Driving Standards Agency (DSA) has reported “promising progress” in ensuring that enough drivers take the training, but experts predict that not enough drivers will hold a CPC certificate in time to meet the deadline. The FTA revealed that 2,980 CPC courses had been approved at 1,195 centres, including Mercedes trucks suppliers, which will supply training for over half a million drivers. However, many drivers have not yet started their training. The FTA’s James Firth said:
"The message to operators is that, if they have not yet started to get their drivers trained, they can still do so in time – but they need to start now," "The Traffic Commissioners have assured the industry that they will take action against drivers found driving without a complete DCPC after the deadline – and also against operators who allow drivers to drive without a complete DCPC,”

item.title: MOT information for HGVs and LCVs
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: As drivers of Mercedes trucks and vans will know, it is a legal requirement for all light commercial vehicles (LCVs) and heavy goods vehicles (HGVs) to undertake regular Ministry of Transport (MOT) tests, just like all other road vehicles. The following is all the basics you need to know about MOT tests for LCVs and HGVs. LCV MOTs A LCV requires its first MOT test once it is three years old. Ideally, this test will be taken on or just before the date the vehicle was first registered. The class of MOT test a LCV will require depends on its weight and model. For example, a Mercedes Sprinter van will require either a Class 4 or a Class 7 MOT test (dependant on the gross weight of the vehicle). HGV MOTs The types of vehicles that are classed as HGVs and require an HGV MOT include semi-trailers, converter dollies, vehicles weighing more than 3,500 kilograms and trailers with an unladen weight of 1,020 kilograms or more. HGVs require their first MOT test when they are one year old. After that, HGVs must pass an MOT test once a year to be considered legally roadworthy and safe.

item.title: Bedroom firm praises ‘fuel-efficient’ fleet of Mercedes Sprinter vans
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A beds and bedroom furniture company with bases all over the UK has praised the fleet of ‘fuel efficient’ Mercedes Sprinter vans it uses to make deliveries to customers. Starplan Bedrooms, which has depots in Warrington and Wednesbury and a distribution centre in Northern Ireland, decided to switch from 7.3 tonne trucks to smaller Mercedes vans after it first introduced its home delivery service. Since making the switch, Starplan and its network of customers, who are located throughout the whole of the UK, have enjoyed a number of benefits. The company is able to save money on fuel using more fuel-efficient vehicles, and the firm’s customers also appreciate that their orders arrive safely and on time in the new Mercedes Sprinter vans. Starplan’s transport manager Steve Whittle commented on the benefits of using the new vans and also shed light on another advantage of using this particular model of Mercedes van. He said:
"There are obvious advantages to running 3.5-tonners - they're cheaper to buy and to run, easier to manoeuvre around residential streets and don't require an Operator's Licence. "But our vehicle bodies must also be tall enough to carry our standard 2220mm-long bed frames vertically - which is unusual in this weight class - as well as providing enough payload capacity to allow us to make multiple deliveries in one journey."

item.title: All you need to know about CPC driver training
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: From September 2009, it became a legal requirement for drivers of LGVs weighing 3.5 tonnes or more to have a Driver Certificate of Professional Competence (CPC). Drivers must complete the 35 hours of training that are required every five years, and get their CPC by September 2014 or they risk losing their licence. It’s not too late to start your CPC training If you want to complete your 35 hours training and get your CPC before the deadline date, it is very important that you book onto a CPC course right away. If you leave it any later, you may not have time to complete your training. This could mean that in September 2014, you may lose your licence. Advice on CPC driver training for fleet managers Fleet managers should also take responsibility for their drivers undertaking CPC driver training. This is because it will negatively impact on the efficiency of their fleet and the productivity of their business if drivers do not reach the CPC requirement and lose their licences. Where to take CPC training There are many places offering CPC training. In particular, Mercedes trucks and vans suppliers offer CPC training courses, which can cover the following topics: •Truck technology and safety •Economical driving •Driving safety •Legal & social legislation •Load securing •The professional driver •The economical driving experience

item.title: Sprinters used as life-saving ambulances for Nairobi hospital
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes Sprinter vans can be used for many purposes, but the latest application for this particular van model happens to save people’s lives. In Nairobi, the Mercedes Sprinter is being used as a highly sophisticated ambulance, known as an Advanced Life Support Unit. There is a huge demand for such a vehicle in a country where roads are so congested that patients often die on the way to hospital. Three specially customised and equipped Mercedes Sprinter vans are now being used by The Nairobi Hospital as Advanced Life Support ambulances. Each boasts a heart-restarting defibrillator, as well as a cardiac monitor, a ventilator, oxygen supply, orthopaedic equipment, a birth delivery kit, medicines and drugs for a range of ailments and a blood sugar machine. Mike Duder, from the Mercedes dealer which supplied the Sprinter vans, elaborated further on what the specially developed vans are capable of, saying:
“These vehicles are the most sophisticated ambulances available in the region. “The interior is big enough to accommodate two nurses and a stretcher for the patient and they have been built with sufficient height for standing and plenty of space for drugs and extra equipment.”

item.title: Hodgson & Hodgson embraces Mercedes Atego
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The thermal and acoustic insulation company Hodgson & Hodgson Group Ltd has reportedly taken delivery of four more Mercedes-Benz commercial vehicles, adding them to its existing fleet of Mercedes trucks and vans. The company, which specialises in thermal and acoustic insulation products as well as being an independent acoustic consultancy, has now taken delivery of not one new Mercedes Atego truck, but three of the 7.5 tonne 818s, as well as a 3.5 tonne Mercedes Sprinter van. All of the new trucks are super fuel-efficient thanks to the Motor Stop Start (MSS) systems that are fitted in each vehicle as standard. Hodgson & Hodgson has relied on Mercedes trucks and vans for more than 12 years. Speaking to Transport Engineer, group purchasing manager Roy Hodgson explained why the company favours Mercedes vehicles over other manufacturers. He said:
"We changed to Mercedes-Benz back in 2000 and it's proved to be a very wise decision," "This is the second time that we've moved three 7.5-tonne Ategos out and replaced them with three more. They have never let us down and have always been reliable, fuel-efficient and popular with our drivers."

item.title: Tips for fleet managers on improving driving efficiency
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: One of the biggest areas of expenditure for fleet managers is the cost of fuel. Managers spend a lot of their time trying to find ways to reduce fuel consumption, but by far the best way to do this is by improving driving efficiency amongst fleet drivers. The following are some useful and practical tips for fleet managers to help them improve driving efficiency and save on fuel costs across their entire fleets: •Invest in GPS navigation systems – these can help drivers find the most efficient routes, avoid traffic and stop them getting lost, all of which can burn up unnecessary fuel and waste driving time. Even better, you can choose vehicles which have in-built GPS systems, such as some Mercedes vans and trucks, for example. •Implement advanced driver training – this can help drivers to drive their vehicles more efficiently, such as teaching them the optimum speeds and gears to drive in, as well as the braking techniques they need to conserve fuel. •Consider the loading of vehicles – ensure that your vans and trucks are properly loaded and aren’t carrying unnecessary weight, as this can burn extra fuel and affect driving efficiency.

item.title: Staffordshire truck dealer invests in new Mercedes trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
J Clarke Transport Ltd, a truck and trailer rental specialist based in Staffordshire, has reportedly become the latest company to take delivery of new Mercedes trucks. The company, which has its headquarters in Tamworth, sent its new Mercedes trucks out to work virtually immediately after taking delivery of them. The new trucks are 4x2 Axor tractor units, each boasting 400hp, 12-litre fuel efficient engines. The trucks, which are plated for operation at 38 tonnes gvw, also have 12-speed Mercedes PowerShift automated transmission systems and standard cabs. The decision to add the Axor trucks to its existing fleet, which also includes six of the very popular Mercedes Sprinter van model, was made based on the reliability of Mercedes vans and trucks the company has used for the last few years. In particular, used Mercedes trucks such as a pre-owned 26-tonne Axor curtainsider vehicle which has served the company for the last four years. Robert Pallett, who is the operations director at J Clarke Transport Ltd, explained:
"That truck has been no trouble at all, just a fabulous vehicle," "This explains why, in addition to the 10 new tractors, we've also recently bought two more secondhand Axors, a 26-tonne curtainsider and an 18-tonne platform with crane."

item.title: Benefits of MSS systems in Mercedes trucks
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: The auto-manufacturer Mercedes-Benz has revealed that many of its new trucks, particularly the manual Mercedes Atego truck and the Axor R truck will be fitted with its innovative Motor Stop Start (MSS) system as standard. But what benefits does the MSS system offer to fleet managers and drivers? How MSS works The MSS system is simple to understand. It works by switching the engine off when the Mercedes truck is stationary, such as at traffic lights, at fuelling stations and in traffic jams. It will automatically activate when the gearbox is in neutral, when it has been stationary for three seconds, the clutch pedal is not depressed and the outside temperature is above 0°C. When the driver is ready to start the vehicle, the intelligent system simply starts the engine back up again. MSS benefits This system has many benefits for drivers, fleet managers and company owners, such as the following: •It saves fuel, as the engine is not left idling when the vehicle is stationary •It also saves fleet managers money on fuel costs •Companies can boast of improved green credentials, as they will be using the MSS system to cut down on fuel consumption and reduce their carbon footprint

item.title: Experts claim condition is the key to selling used vans
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
For fleet managers, a big part of the job is replacing older, less efficient vans with new models. This often means selling the old vans at auction, but it can sometimes be difficult to get the best price or even to sell the van at all. Experts have now come up with some top tips for fleet managers on how to sell their used Mercedes vans and other vehicles at auction, and get the very best price for them. The key, apparently is condition. Most fleet managers know that scruffy, dirty, damaged and worn-out looking vans will never sell, as buyers at auction are experienced at spotting used vans that will require a lot of effort and money to bring back to life. This is why it is essential to carry out some basic maintenance on your vans before putting them up for sale, but how much work is it cost-effective to do. Experts recommend taking steps when you first buy the van, such as ply-lining it and fitting a reversing sensor to protect the interiors and exteriors respectively. When it comes to sale time, commercial vehicles expert Duncan Ward has this recommendation to make:
“Proper preparation and good presentation are vital if your LCVs are going to achieve the best possible price at auction. With the demand for well-presented vans, there is a massive opportunity for sellers. “Smart preparation – the process of bringing vehicles back to ‘showroom condition’ through paint technology, cold metal dent removal and repairs to interior and trim – has an important role.”

item.title: Mercedes-Benz M-Class voted most attractive car by German magazine readers
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Anyone who has ever had the privilege of driving Mercedes trucks, vans or cars will know something of the style and elegance in design that the manufacturer is known for. The attractiveness of Mercedes vehicles has now been officially recognised, after the readers of the German car magazine Auto Bild voted the Mercedes-Benz M-Class the most attractive car of the year in its category. The M-Class SUV was entered into the SUV/Vans/All-wheel drive category and was voted the winner and ‘Germany’s most attractive car’ in the Auto Bild Design Awards 2012 by more than 100,000 reader votes. Commenting on its success in the awards was the director of sales and marketing for Mercedes Benz Cars and Daimler Middle East, Frank Bernthaler. He said:
"After more than 125 years, the three pointed star continues to draw the highest praises and admiration from those with a deep appreciation for design and innovation. These highly respected awards from both industry experts and consumers further assert our position as luxury automotive design leader in a highly competitive segment."
This isn’t the only design award Mercedes is currently celebrating, as its Mercedes Actros truck was recently honoured with a red dot product design award.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz named red dot: client of the year 2012
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
It has just been announced that the German auto-manufacturer Mercedez-Benz will be the lucky recipient of the ‘red dot: client of the year 2012’ award, although the official award ceremony will only take place towards the end of the month. The award has been presented to the company as a whole in recognition of its innovative and pioneering work in the fields of marketing and communication. However, several Mercedes-Benz products have also been honoured with the red dot commendation. Amongst the vehicles which have won red dot product design awards this year are the Mercedes Actros truck, C-Class Couple, B-Class and the SLS AMG. In addition, the Mercedes eBike also won the ‘red dot: best of the best’ award. Commenting on its tremendous achievement in the red dot awards 2012, the Head of Brand Communications for Mercedes-Benz Cars released a statement. Anders Sundt Jensen proudly explained how much the accolade means to the auto manufacturer, saying:
“We are delighted, and tremendously proud, to receive this accolade,” “It is a great reward for us and our creative agencies after a year of intensive but ultimately successful hard work.”

item.title: Battery-electric Mercedes Sprinter van unveiled at Motor Show
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
According to a report by EV World, the auto maker Mercedes-Benz has unveiled a brand new battery-electric version of its highly successful Mercedes Sprinter van.
The new van was revealed at the 2012 International Motor Show (IAA) for commercial vehicles, where the company demonstrated the benefits of battery-electric powered vans. The new Mercedes Sprinter van, known as the Sprinter E-CELL, was produced as a prototype at the event. If the public reaction is positive overall, the new Sprinter could be made into a new series.
The prototype, consisting of a driver’s cab and middle wheelbase of 3665mm, was developed from the company’s expertise in creating the E-CELL version of the Mercedes Vito van. Currently, 500 E-CELL Mercedes Vito vans are in use, and the model is available to buy in over 15 European countries.
The E-CELL Sprinter van uses similar technology to the Vito, but it has a whole new chassis and rear-wheel drive and is also in a completely different weight class. Thanks to a permanent magnet synchronous motor and the power of two lithium-ion battery packs, the new Sprinter will be able to reach an impressive constant output of 70kW.

item.title: Security advice for fleet managers – how to protect both drivers and vehicles
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: Unfortunately, trucks and vans are often targeted by potential thieves and vandals, especially those tasked with transporting valuable goods. This makes security a huge issue for fleet managers. But what can you do to ensure that drivers, vehicles and goods are protected? Here are a few suggestions. Vehicle tracking systems Want to know where your vehicle is at all times? Vehicle tracking systems will give you real-time updates on the location of your Mercedes trucks and vans, as well as the speed and direction they are travelling. This can help you to ensure your drivers are on the correct routes, as well as enabling you to track lost or stolen vehicles quickly and easily. Remote vehicle disabling systems One system that is even better than lock and alarm systems is remote vehicle disabling, which effectively locks out intruders and prevents them from stealing a vehicle. These systems, which you may find in Mercedes vans and trucks or can add to these kinds of vehicles, allow you to remotely stop or slow a vehicle or prevent the engine from starting in the first place. Panic and emergency notification systems A part of remote disabling systems that your drivers may find useful is panic and notification systems. These enable drivers to press a panic button or key fob and send an emergency alert should they need to.

item.title: How to customise your Mercedes Vito van
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: Like many Mercedes vans and trucks, the Mercedes Vito van can be customised to suit the owner or driver’s personal specifications. It comes in a range of customisable colours and trims, as well as a vast inventory of optional equipment to choose from. Choose your colour and trim The Mercedes Vito van comes in a vast range of different metallic paint finishes, from artic red and pebble grey to flame red to atlantis blue. However, depending where you buy your van from, there is the potential to choose from as many as 100 colour options. Pick out optional extra equipment What extra equipment you choose for your Mercedes Vito van depends on what you plan to use your vehicle for. Options include: •Cargo retention grille •COMAND APS navigation system •Body coloured bumpers •Hinged rear doors •Bi-xenon headlamps •Twin co-driver’s seat with table function Other features which come as standard with Vito vans are front power windows and a loading facility under the seat. Now that you know what options are available, it’s up to you to tailor and customise your perfect Mercedes Vito van to meet your needs.

item.title: New Mercedes Sprinter vans ordered by Welsh delivery firm
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A delivery company operating in areas of Cheshire and North Wales has recently revealed that it has invested a total of £278,000 adding 17 new vehicles to its fleet, 15 of which are new Mercedes vans. Delsol, which is based in both Caernarfon and Sandycroft, is currently undergoing a massive expansion. Alongside growing staff numbers and boosting turnover, the company has decided to add 15 new Mercedes Sprinter vans to bring its fleet up to 56 vehicles. The directors of Delsol, Tony Parry and Simon Walker, are hoping that the new vehicles will help the company secure more than £5 million in turnover. The timing of the investment is very good too, as the delivery firm is expecting a huge demand for its services in the run-up to the Christmas period. Mr Parry said of the new additions to its fleet:
“It is fantastic to receive these new vehicles which will ramp up our ability to grow and provide a faster, more efficient and more cost effective service, “We are determined to become the ‘go to’ transport firm for parcel and pallet services in North Wales and Cheshire.”

item.title: Safety features of Mercedes Citan and Vito vans compared
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: If you are considering adding Mercedes vans to your fleet, it is likely that safety will be one of the main things you are looking for. After all, you have drivers and goods to protect, as well as the vans themselves. To help you choose the right Mercedes vans for you, here are the safety features of the Mercedes Citan and the Mercedes Vito for you to compare. Mercedes Citan When designing the Citan, Mercedes designers and engineers made safety a top priority. Safety features they included in the design are as follows: •Traction Control System (TCS) •Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) •Drive and braking torque control •Accelerations Skid Control (ASR) •Vehicle Dynamic Control (VDC) All of these safety features are a part of the Electric Stability Program ADAPTIVE ESP, the dynamic handling control system which comes as standard in Mercedes Citan vans. Mercedes Vito Safety was just as important for the designers of the Mercedes Vito van as it was for Citan. With safety in mind, the Vito van was fitted with: •Electronic Stability Program ADAPTIVE ESP (the same system that the Mercedes Citan is fitted with) •Front airbag for driver •Optional window air bags and front airbag for co-driver •Bi-xenon headlamps with integrated cornering light function

item.title: All you need to know about the efficiency of the Mercedes Vito van
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
For many individuals looking to buy a new Mercedes van, and especially for fleet managers wanting to buy multiple new vans, efficiency is a very important quality to look out for. This is possibly why the Mercedes Vito van has proved itself so popular in the last couple of years, because it runs more economically and efficiently than many of its competitors in the same class and category.
Let’s find out some more about the efficiency of the Vito van, starting with the fact that Mercedes has fitted each of its new Vito vans with either an economical 4-cyclinder CDI diesel engine or a V6 CDI diesel engine. These engines both meet EU/5 emissions standards, as well as consuming less fuel and emitting lower levels of harmful exhaust gas than the Vito vans which came before it.
New Mercedes Vito vans are also fitted with:
•Resistance optimised tyres •Intelligent energy management systems •ECO Gear transmission, an all-new system •ECO start/stop functioning •On demand fuel pump •Shift point display
All of these features, plus the economical and efficient engines fitted in Vito vans, are part of Mercedes unique BlueEFFICIENCY package. These efficient features are also what makes Vito vans amongst the finest examples of sustainable transportation currently on the market.

item.title: Eurovision Logistics buys flagship Mercedes Actros truck
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The Hull-based haulage company Eurovision Logistics has proudly announced that it has taken delivery of its very first new Mercedes Actros truck, which will be the flagship Mercedes vehicle for its fleet. Amongst the features which particularly impressed the company’s managing director Dominic Yeardley were the New Actros’ imposing GigaSpace cab, incredible fuel-efficiency and gleaming silver paintwork. Mr Yeardley also elaborated on how he expects the new fleet vehicle to benefit the company over time, saying:
"Experience tells me that a truck needs a few thousand kilometres under its belt before the fuel figures start to look good. "But the Daimler Fleetboard telematics hardware showed the New Actros averaging 9.3 mpg straight 'out of the box'. That's a very impressive figure, significantly better than any of our comparable vehicles. And of course, we expect it to improve as the truck continues to bed in."
The New Mercedes Actros truck will join Eurovision Logistics’ existing fleet of 80 vehicles and according to Mr Yeardley, it will be responsible for undertaking long-haul Continental deliveries. It will be travelling on long trips to destinations such as Southern Italy, and has been fitted with auxiliary air-conditioning which works when the engine is off to keep the vehicle cool in the very hot temperatures in European countries such as Italy.

item.title: Eco-benefits of the Vito E-CELL
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: The Mercedes Vito E-CELL is unlike any other van in the Vito range, and this is because it runs on an electric battery. The vehicle is designed to be more efficient and more eco-friendly than any of its predecessors, offering owners and drivers a host of eco-benefits. Easy, fast charging The Vito E-CELL has two high-energy density lithium-ion batteries which can be easily charged using a specially installed charging station or a 240v plug and adapter cable. It takes approximately 6 hours to charge the Vito E-CELL’s battery from empty using a charging station, or 12 hours (it is recommended to charge overnight) from a plug and adaptor set-up. Battery range and payload The Vito E-CELL boasts two impressive specifications – a 775kg payload and an 80 mile (approximate) range on a full battery charge. RBS for extra charging This van has a unique feature that no other vehicle in its class can claim, and this is a recuperative braking system (RBS). The RBS converts braking energy into electricity for the motor, recharging the Vito E-CELL as you drive it and further extending the vehicle’s range. Ideal for city driving One particular benefit of the Vito E-CELL for drivers (and particular taxi drivers using Vito vans) working in city centres is that the vehicle has been designed with city operation in mind. In particular, it will benefit drivers working in environmentally sensitive locations such as the London Low Emission Zone (LEZ).

item.title: Brazilian government orders 2,100 Mercedes trucks and vans
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The Daimler Motor Company, which makes Mercedes Benz vans and trucks, has revealed that it has received an order for more than 2,000 commercial vehicles from the Brazilian government. The order consists of a total of 2,100 vehicles, including 1,700 Mercedes Atego trucks and 400 Mercedes Sprinter vans, which the Brazilian government will deploy in various areas. The primary use of the Sprinter vans will be as ambulances for the Ministry of Health. The Atego trucks, meanwhile, will be delivered to the Ministry of Defence. Commenting on the manufacturer’s success in winning the government tenders was Jürgen Ziegler, who is the President of Mercedes-Benz do Brazil, the Brazilian arm of the company, and the CEO of Latin America. Mr Ziegler said:
“We are happy that the Brazilian government continues to place trust in our Mercedes-Benz products. Our state-of-the-art technology, convincing quality, and low total cost ownership are attractive purchasing arguments for our customers,”
Amongst the reasons for Mercedes-Benz winning the tenders were the superior quality and broad usage profile of the vehicles it supplies. Mercedes-Benz in Brazil has already started delivering the order, but the full fleet the government requires will be fully complete sometime in 2013.

item.title: Winter accessories for Mercedes vehicles
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: The onset of winter means a whole new set of challenges for fleet managers and commercial vehicles drivers to prepare for and overcome. Luckily, there are plenty of ways to prepare vehicles for winter snow, sleet and ice, as well as measures that drivers can take to prevent accidents and breakdowns. The following are a few of the essential winter accessories available for Mercedes vehicles. If your fleet uses Mercedes trucks or vans, you will find some or all of these accessories highly useful in the next few months. Windscreen accessories It is vital that drivers of Mercedes trucks and other vehicles have a clear, unobstructed view of the road at all times, especially in winter when there are so many more hazards to look out for. These accessories can help in the battle against ice, frost and winter sludge thrown up from the road: •Ice scrapers •Defrosting agents •Windscreen concentrate •Anti-freeze and de-icer products Wheel and tyre accessories Winter driving can be hazardous, but you can prepare the wheels of your Mercedes vans for snow-covered roads with snow socks. These are fitted to the drive wheels of Mercedes Sprinter and Vito vans to give drivers more stability and control in difficult road surfaces and driving conditions.

item.title: Mercedes unveils brand new Antos truck for Europe
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Truck and van manufacturer Mercedes-Benz has released a brand new upgrade to one of its commercial vehicles, the all-new Mercedes Antos truck, onto the European market.
Launched in September 2012, the new Mercedes Antos is an upper medium duty distribution truck with a huge list of impressive features and functions. Notable specifications include the following:
•Complies with Euro VI emissions standard due to compliant 6-cylinder engines •Low weight - even the larger Antos 428hp model only weighs around 6400 kg •Aluminium entrance support •Weight optimised windscreen and floor coverings •Combined tank for AdBlue and fuel •Available in three sizes - OM 936 with 7.7 L, OM 470 with 10.7 L, and OM 471 with 12.8 L •Available in a range of 13 power options from 175 kW to 375kW •Available as a platform truck or a tractor unit •Axle spacing ranging from 2,650 mm to 6,700 mm
The new Antos also features some of the most impressive aspects of its Mercedes Actros truck design, including a full suite of safety systems and predictive powertrain control. The distinctive styling, as well as the spacious interiors and easy functionality, of the new Antos also echoes that of the Mercedes Actros.

item.title: Customising the new Mercedes Vito to suit you
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: Like most other vans in the Mercedes range, the Mercedes Vito van can be customised and personalised in a vast number of ways. The manufacturer knows that all business users have different needs and specifications, and to meet this demand the Vito has been made as versatile and flexible as possible. So, the only question is – how will you customise your Mercedes Vito? Dualiner or panel van? The new Mercedes Vito comes in two versions. The first is the panel van, offering a huge load compartment, a low loading sill and large door openings. The other option is the Vito Dualiner, designed to carry both passengers and goods and equipment. Size There are three main options to choose from when you order a Mercedes Vito van. There is compact, for city drivers in need of a highly manoeuvrable model where extra space isn’t a top priority. There are also long and extra-long versions of the Vito available, the former having a higher roof and extra length and the latter giving users an extra-long load compartment. Paintwork As with all Mercedes vans and trucks, the Vito can be customised in terms of colour and trim. Choose from a huge range of colours and finishes, from classic arctic white to vibrant flame red. Accessories In addition to the colour and size of your Vito, we also have a wide range of accessories available for you to choose from  so you can really make it your own.  Take a look at our Vito Accessories Brochure

item.title: Mercedes trucks the first to receive EU certification for AEBS
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Auto manufacturer Daimler AG has been presented with the first European certificate of approval for its use of Advanced Emergency Braking Systems (AEBS) in Mercedes-Benz trucks.
The certification was announced at this year’s Internationale Automobil-Ausstellung (IAA), where Daimler was deemed to have met the international Regulation relating to AEBS in two of its Mercedes trucks.
The Mercedes Actros and the brand new Mercedes Antos, which was also launched at the IAA 2012, have been proven to meet the legal requirements of the new Regulation. The requirements will not actually become mandatory for vehicles in certain categories until 2018 when the second stage of the Regulation takes effect, but Mercedes-Benz has shown that it is already ahead of the curve.
Whilst many trucks from other manufacturers meet the requirements of the first stage of the Regulation, Mercedes trucks fitted with the ABA 3 emergency braking system are the only ones which currently comply with AEBS Stage 2. This technically makes Mercedes trucks amongst the safest in Europe in relation to braking, and Mercedes Actros trucks have long been considered the safest trucks of their kind in the world.

item.title: Nidera’s invests in five new Mercedes Actros trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The grain merchant Nidera’s has reportedly taken delivery of five New Mercedes Actros trucks to add to its 44-vehicle strong fleet, and the company may soon be planning to place a further order of six more Actros trucks next year if all goes well. The new Actros trucks boast a number of impressive features, such as 450bhp engines and StreamSpace cabs. The vehicles also make use of Mercedes PowerShift 3 12-speed automated transmissions and use the Daimler FleetBoard telematics system to analyse driver performance and prevent efficiency-reducers such as harsh braking, speeding and over-revving. Speaking of the new purchases, Nidera’s General Manager of Industrial Operations Tim Capey commented:
"We've heard a lot of good things about New Actros, particularly in terms of fuel consumption," "Mercedes-Benz was talking at the launch about an improvement in economy of up to 7%," "Given the fact that the previous Actros is itself a highly fuel-efficient vehicle, if the new model comes even close to that figure, then it's an easy decision." "They've only been on the road for a few weeks so it's too early yet to comment on the mpg returns, but we're certainly very pleased with our New Actros."

item.title: Mercedes Actros truck wins two design awards
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The new and improved version of the Mercedes Actros truck has been honoured with two very prestigious awards for its innovative design. The new Actros has won the Focus in Gold 2012 award as well as the German Design Award 2013 in the category of Transportation and Public Space from the Design Centre Stuttgart. The Design Award will be officially presented at the Ambiente trade fair in Frankfurt in February 2013. The 30-member jury at the Design Centre, which reportedly received more than 1,500 submissions from vehicles in ten main categories, was reportedly won over by the high quality and ergonomic design of the Actros’ interiors, as well as the consistent standards of exterior design in variants of the Actros. These two new awards can now be added to the Red Dot design award that the Actros received from the Design Zentrum Nordrhein-Westfalen, making it one of Mercedes-Benz most successful trucks in terms of design. Commenting on the most recent awards, commercial vehicle design director for Mercedes-Benz, Kai Sieber, said:
“We are incredibly proud of how perfectly form follows function in the new Actros. That's why we naturally are very pleased about this special recognition in the form of these coveted international design awards,"

item.title: Cardiff company replaces Vito vans with brand new long-body models
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A telephone systems supplier based in Cardiff has finally stood down its fleet of Mercedes Vito vans, only to replace the vehicles with brand new versions of the trusty Vito van. TWL Voice & Data has recently taken delivery of five new long-bodied Vito vans. The order consists of a 113CDI Dualiner with a 136hp engine, a Vito 116CDI Sport with a 163hp engine and three Mercedes Vito 113CDI panel vans. Marketing manager for TWL Voice & Data, Andrew Hirst, explained why the company had decided to retire its current fleet and replace the vehicles with brand new Mercedes models. He said:
"Our new vehicles are even better than their predecessors. The Euro 5 engines are cleaner and more economical, and they have extra standard specification details such as multi-function steering wheels which control their Bluetooth telephone systems, cruise controls and speed limiters. We've also added optional parking sensors." "Our customers rely on us so with a workload like that our vehicles must be completely reliable, as well as fuel efficient and comfortable," "The new Vito easily meets all these criteria and our engineers are delighted with them."

item.title: Advice on buying remanufactured Mercedes parts
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: Money’s tight these days, leaving many of us looking for ways to save money and get great deals on the things we really need to buy. One unavoidable cost is a replacement for a car part which has worn out or malfunctioned. When searching for new car parts for your Mercedes, you may come across remanufactured car parts which are cheaper than buying the parts brand new. But are these parts as good quality as you’d expect, or are they a waste of money? Remanufactured Mercedes parts can be really good value for money, as well as good for the environment as they are made from existing parts rather than being made from scratch with raw materials. However, to get good value and good quality when buying remanufactured car parts, you need to make sure that you: • Buy from a reputable seller, preferably from a manufacturer specialising in Mercedes parts • Ensure you get a good warranty. Remanufactured parts such as Reman80 Genuine Parts, sold by Mercedes, offer the same 2 year unlimited mileage warranty that you’d get with any other new Mercedes-Benz product • Beware of incredibly low prices – if a deal seems too good to be true, it probably is. For further information and  to purchase Reman80 Genuine Parts contact S & B Commercials on 01707 263333 or click here

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter still in top 10 of most reliable UK vans
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A new survey commissioned to find out which are the most reliable vans amongst UK fleet owners has placed the Mercedes Sprinter van in the top ten for a second year running.
The survey, commissioned by Fleet News, is an annual analysis of the top fifty leasing companies (FN50) in the UK according to fleet size. Respondents were asked to rank the best vans, as well as cars, in terms of reliability.
Topping the list in 2011 for FN50 companies was the Mercedes Sprinter van, which was deemed the most reliable van in the UK. It has been knocked down to third in this year’s poll by the Ford Transit and Transit Connect vans, which came just below it at fourth and second places respectively in the 2011 survey.
The battle between these two rivals may be set to continue, and as Mercedes constantly develops its vehicles to outdo their competitors in terms of reliability, safety and performance, we could see the Sprinter back at the top of the FN50 survey results in 2013.
As well as placing the Sprinter van third in the 2012 survey results, Mercedes also had another van in the top ten. The Mercedes Vito, another of the manufacturer’s most popular vehicles, ranked at number six in terms of reliability.

item.title: The many uses of the Mercedes Econic truck
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: There are many things that can influence a vehicle’s popularity amongst its users, such as reliability and safety, for example. One of the factors that has made the Mercedes Econic truck such an enduringly popular model, however, is its versatility. The Mercedes Econic truck has been designed so that it can adapt to many different uses and applications easily. For example, the Econic is used for: •Waste collection. Thanks to the Econic’s innovative low-floor concept and impressive cargo volume and payload, it is ideal for use in the waste collection industry. •Distribution. The Mercedes Econic truck has an eco-friendly gas engine, which is perfect for companies operating in urban or environmental zones and which have green targets to meet. •Fire and emergency. As the Econic has a spacious cab capable of accommodating four occupants, it makes an ideal vehicle for fire and emergency services. It also has a height of less than three metres, even with a turntable ladder system fitted, meaning it can reach emergency sites quickly without having to avoid underpasses. •Airport ground services (i.e. catering vehicles, fuel tankers). With its good body-mounting ability, low-floor frame, low centre of gravity and optional scissor lift, the Econic is perfectly suited to airfield applications.

item.title: International freight forwarder invests in Mercedes trucks
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A freight forwarding company based in Essex but with operations running all over the world has announced its investment in a total of 15 new Mercedes trucks. Woodland Logistics, which has seven UK offices and a total of five hundred staff throughout the UK, Ireland, Europe, America, Asia and the Middle East, has just won itself an important five-year contract renewal with leading packaging manufacturer Cepac Limited. To fulfil its duties with regards to its South Yorkshire based client, Woodland will need a whole new fleet of vehicles. The truck of choice for Woodlands Logistics is the Mercedes Actros truck, a tractor unit with an impressive reputation for functionality and reliability. 15 Mercedes Actros trucks have been purchased and will soon be on the road, helping the company to service its clients and build its reputation. Sean Kirby, who is the managing director for Woodlands, explained how the company will embark on its new contract:
“The Woodland management team work closely with Cepac’s sales and production teams to maximise load fill rate and vehicle efficiencies throughout the supply chain, helping Cepac to retain and win new business. The main aspect is that the fleet is a lot more economical, our trucks are all full, and so we are maximising utilisation there.”

item.title: New Mercedes Actros named Ireland Truck of the Year 2013
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The new Mercedes Actros truck has been named Irish Truck of the Year 2013, after impressing judges in a number of key areas. The Actros was apparently developed around four key areas, and these were driving dynamics, economy, comfort and extended product range. When it came to deciding which vehicle was to be named Irish Truck of the Year 2013, however, the areas to be judged were: •Comfort •Safety •Fuel consumption •Driveability •Innovation •Emission reduction The Mercedes-Benz Actros, one of the manufacturer’s most popular vehicles in its class, scored well in every category. Presenting the award to Mercedes-Benz was David Spence, marketing manager for Chevron Lubricants. Upon accepting the accolade, sales manager for Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles Ireland, Fergus Conheady, said:
“We are delighted to have received this prestigious award from the Irish Truck of the Year jury for our New Actros. This award has confirmed our belief that we have created a truly revolutionary vehicle. The New Actros is the most fuel-efficient truck Mercedes-Benz has ever built.”
As well as receiving the 2013 award, the Mercedes Actros also won it back in 2004 and in 2009 with the company’s MP3 version.

item.title: Service and breakdown advice for Mercedes van fleet operators
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: If you run a fleet of Mercedes vans, you will know how essential it is to keep all vehicles on the road as much as possible and to avoid breakdowns and downtime at all costs. The key to operating an efficient fleet is regular servicing, along with having emergency plans in place for unexpected breakdowns, faulty parts and other malfunctions. MobilityGo Mercedes van fleet managers will be pleased to know that there is now a plan in place to ensure your business keeps moving in case of breakdowns or warranty problems. It is called MobilityGo, and it is available to all businesses and fleet managers who bought vans from authorised UK Mercedes-Benz dealers in the last two years. If your business is signed up to MobilityGo, it means you are automatically entitled to fast roadside assistance in case vehicles won’t start or suffer mechanical breakdown whilst out on the road. This ensures that problems are quickly resolved and your Mercedes vans are able to get back to work in as short a time as possible. This ultimately ensures that the business remains as productive, efficient and profitable as possible.

item.title: New Mercedes Actros a part of Dunne Group expansion
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A building contractor based in Scotland has recently taken delivery of a brand new Mercedes Actros truck, and plans to use it as part of its expansion plans in the South of England. Dunne Group, a building and civil engineering contractor with a head office in the West Lothian town of Bathgate, has decided to expand into the South of England by setting up a new depot in London. In order to service this new depot, a new, efficient and highly reliable vehicle was required, prompting the company to order a new Mercedes Actros tractor unit. The New Actros 2545 is powered by a 450bhp straight-six engine and has the very latest Mercedes-Benz PowerShift 3 automated transmission. The Mercedes truck has also been fitted with an aerodynamic StreamSpace cab. Commenting on the decision to order the new Mercedes Actros and describing the work it will be put to, operations director for the Dunne Group, John McCormack, said:
"We already run some Actros trucks so we know they are efficient and reliable," "It's making an average of 10 trips up and down the M6 and M1 each week, which means it's highly visible and is certainly fulfilling our requirement for a smart flagship truck to raise the profile of our business."

item.title: Is your fleet adhering to LEZ regulations?
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
In January 2012, fleet managers operating within the nation’s capital were faced with a new challenge – adhering to the new, far stricter standards of the Low Emission Zone (LEZ) in London.
The LEZ, which covers most of Greater London, requires vehicles to meet certain standards when it comes to emissions and pollutants. These standards are called the Euro 3 (for vans) and Euro 4 (for trucks) and they impose strict limitations on the amount of particulate matter coming from vehicle exhausts.
If your fleet’s vehicles do not meet the Euro 3 or Euro 4 standards, you will have to pay a daily charge. Over time, these costs can add up and start eating into your business’ profits.
There are two main choices for fleet managers whose vehicles do not yet meet the LEZ emissions standards but who want to base their businesses in Greater London. These options are to replace your existing fleet with compliant vehicles or to modify your vehicles so that they meet the requirements.
If you are planning to replace your vehicles and you need vans fit for city driving, a good choice would be Mercedes Vito vans or Mercedes Sprinter vans.

item.title: New Actros made with innovative Dolphin process
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Since the new Mercedes Actros was first launched back in June 2011, it has become one of the most popular and well-reviewed vehicles of its class. As well as being used by fleets and businesses up and down the country, the new Actros has even won two prestigious design awards, the Focus in Gold 2012 Award and the German Design Award (Transportation and Public Space) 2013.
So, what is the key to Mercedes’ success with the Actros? The answer could be found inside the vehicle, in the Actros’ impressive interiors.
As well as being cost efficient, fuel efficient and delivering exceptional performance, the Actros truck also boasts high comfort levels. This can be attributed to a soft-touch cockpit which has been injection moulded using the innovative Dolphin process.
The Dolphin process combines two-component hard/soft moulding with foamed-in-place technology. In the New Actros, the first application of the Dolphin process that is in serial production, it has been used to create a dashboard extending across the entire 2 metre width of the vehicle and featuring TPE soft-touch surfaces with what is known as "differentiated skin grain zones".

item.title: Double the Success for Mercedes-Benz Vans at What Van? Awards 2013
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: Mercedes-Benz has scooped two top awards at the 2013 What Van? Awards. The Sprinter won “4x4 Van of the Year 2013” while Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles won the “Safety Award 2013”. Steve Bridge, Van Sales and Marketing Director for Mercedes-Benz UK, said: “As a manufacturer, we have always pioneered new standards in terms of driver and pedestrian protection and we are delighted to have won the What Van? Award for Safety following our success in 2012. “Mercedes-Benz has led the way in safety innovations, including creating the airbag in 1980 and launching ESP in 1995, making it standard across our vehicles in 1999. Our vans have however, always gone one stage further and are now using Adaptive ESP which automatically measures the current load condition to react with just the right amount of force to suit the driving situation. This works in conjunction with ABS, disc brakes all round, acceleration skid control, electronic brake force distribution and Brake Assist to ensure that Mercedes-Benz produce vans with safety always as standard.” Paul Barker, Editor of What Van?, added: “Mercedes-Benz is the undoubted light commercial vehicle leader in terms of its approach to safety, and its attitude is something other manufacturers should be seeking to follow as the company continues to innovate and ensure its vehicles are as safe as possible for employees. We are also impressed with the Sprinter 4x4's ability to combine good on- and off-road performance in a way no other van can." The What Van? Awards have been the UK’s top light commercial vehicle honours for more than two decades, awarded over 12 categories and decided by the title’s expert editorial team that share decades of LCV experience.   For more information about the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter click here or talk to our Van Sales Executives on 01707 261111.

item.title: Double order of Mercedes Actros trucks for delighted logistics service
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A logistics company based in Taunton and Evercreech has just invested in an order of six New Mercedes Actros trucks – just weeks after ordering four of the vehicles. Peter Green Chilled, a company specialising in providing temperature controlled logistics services to the food industry, was so pleased with its first batch of New Actros tractor units that a new order was placed virtually right away. All of the Mercedes trucks joining the existing fleet will be flat-floored 2545 vehicles with 450bhp engines mated to Mercedes PowerShift 3 automated transmissions. They also come with comfortable and roomy BigSpace cabs, which will no doubt please the company’s fleet of drivers. Explaining why the company choose to add the ten Actros trucks to its 90-strong fleet, transport manager for Peter Green Chilled, Colin Davis, said:
"We've had our first New Actros trucks for a month now and the drivers are really pleased with them, not least because they're so quiet and smooth," "These trucks are already matching the fleet average, in terms of fuel efficiency, which, considering they're still virtually brand new, is very impressive," "Once they start to bed in, the mpg performance is only going to get better."

item.title: Mercedes unveils 2013 Arocs dump truck
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Just weeks after wowing at the 2012 Miami Auto Show with four of its newest consumer models, Mercedes-Benz has unveiled a brand new commercial model for the year ahead. The 2013 Arocs truck will make its official debut to consumer markets in April 2013 at the Bauma trade fair. For now, however, the auto maker is previewing its new commercial model. In a press release announcing the upcoming launch of the Mercedes Arocs dump truck, the company revealed some key specifications about the vehicle. For starters, the Arocs will be offered with a choice of 16 Euro VI-complaint engines, outputs of which will vary from 238 hp (175 kW) to 625 hp (460 kW). Mercedes PowerShift 3 automated transmission will be fitted as standard in all versions of the Arocs, just like in many other Mercedes trucks. The official Mercedes-Benz press released also stated:
"The unmistakeable design of the new Mercedes-Benz Arocs is as unusual as the complete truck. The specially designed styling of the construction truck family stands out because of its radiator grille with so-called bucket-teeth- look. It sends a clear message: the sturdy "teeth" stand for biting one's way through and knuckling down to the job.”

item.title: A closer look at: Mercedes-Benz Vario
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: Mercedes-Benz has become known not just for its ground-breaking consumer vehicles, but also its tailor-made models for the commercial and industrial sectors. There are a number of Mercedes vans available, from the Mercedes Sprinter to the Mercedes Vito van. One very useful and versatile model that is often overlooked, however, is the Mercedes Vario van. Key specifications The Vario comes in two different model types, as do many other Mercedes vans. These are the Panel Van and the Chassis Cab. The Panel Van offers: •Sliding door on left of cargo compartment or on both sides (optional) •Steps at all doors •Three different body lengths •Load volume of up to 17.4 m³. The Chassis Cab, meanwhile, boasts: •Potential payload of up to 4,575kg •Choice of four different body lengths •Choice of standard or crewcab •Special body options and possibilities All models offer 6-speed manual transmission, cost-effective compliance with Euro V (thanks to BlueTEC SCR diesel technology), a strong, robust, ladder-type frame, easy handling and easy loading. What and who is the Mercedes Vario designed for? Like other Mercedes vans, the Vario has a broad range of different applications, whether its nipping across the city with urgent deliveries or sensitive items or transporting bulk goods, packaged shipments or even teams of workers.

item.title: Distribution firm praises the new Mercedes Actros truck
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A distribution company based in Lancashire has taken delivery of its first New Mercedes Actros truck, and the reports of its performance so far are very good. Allan Booth Haulage, a hazardous chemicals distribution specialist based in Burscough, near the Lancashire town of Ormskirk, is delighted with its new Actros truck, claiming that it is even better than the Mercedes trucks the company has used for years. The company, which is family owned, first bought a Mercedes truck back in 1996 and has opted for Mercedes vehicles ever since. The New Actros 2545 StreamSpace is the latest addition to the fleet, enetering service to run alongside some of the firm’s more established trailers and trucks. Speaking of the latest recruit in the Allan Booth Haulage family, proprietor Malcolm Booth explained:
"We'd heard a lot of positive things about New Actros, particularly regarding fuel economy, so carried out a 'back-to-back' comparison to see for ourselves exactly how good it is," “The New Actros certainly lived up to its billing - from brand new it was a full half a mile per gallon better than the other truck, which itself was only six months old."

item.title: Wessex Water drivers test out the new Mercedes Actros
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
After being asked to evaluate trucks, drivers from water company Wessex Water have given the new Mercedes Actros a glowing report. The drivers, from Wessex Water’s sludge operations team, were taking part in a truck evaluations exercise. The trials were staged to help the company decide which would be the best trucks to use in its fleet. The New Actros truck from Mercedes-Benz came out on top with the company’s drivers, leading to Wessex Water ordering 10 of the tractor units to work with its tank trailers. The new Mercedes Actros trucks are 2545 versions which come with ClassicSpace cabs. The vehicles also have 450bhp engines and Mercedes PowerShift 3 automated transmissions. Martin Crocker, Wessex Water’s group manager for fleet and plant and the man responsible for a fleet of 800 vans, 200 cars and 100 vacuum tankers and tippers, explained that the main feature of the trucks that impressed the company’s drivers was the FleetBoard telematics hardware. He said:
"FleetBoard is an excellent system, because it allows us to concentrate our training efforts on those areas where the biggest improvements in driver behaviour can be achieved."

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter vans embark on a Pink Adventure
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Of all Mercedes vans, the Sprinter is known to be one of the most versatile, being used for everything from commercial distribution and delivery to providing ambulance services. However, a company based in Arizona in the U.S. has found a whole new use for the Mercedes Sprinter van. Pink Jeep Tours, a company which operates out of the city of Sedona, is to use the Mercedes Sprinter to launch Pink Adventure Tours in Scottsdale. The new tour route will take tourists from hotels in the Verde Valley region to Sedona and also to the Grand Canyon. The five 10-passenger Mercedes Sprinter vans needed for the full-day tours will be ordered in hot metallic pink to suit the company’s image and will also be customised with leather seats and flat-screen TV screens, the latter of which will be used by Pink Adventure Tours guides to give information about the geology, history and points of interest along the tour routes. Grant Ferguson, who is the chief marketing officer for Pink Jeep Tours, explained his hopes for the brand new Pink Adventure Tours, saying:
“We want to have pink dominance of the Canyon,”

item.title: Advice for fleet managers on simplifying annual safety inspections
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: Along with efficiency and performance, safety is a huge priority for fleet managers. However, it can be a time-consuming and challenging task keeping up with the paperwork, records and checks needed to ensure that a large fleet of vehicles is meeting all safety regulations. Technology has now come to the rescue for paperwork-swamped fleet managers, in the form of an internet-based system enabling easy tracking, filing and archiving of all information relating to truck maintenance and safety inspection schedules. There are a couple of similar systems available, but one of the best is Truckfile, which is specially recommended for fleets containing Mercedes trucks by the manufacturer itself. Truckfile is also approved by the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA). What is Truckfile and what does it do? This product allows fleet managers to record all documentation and records for fleets of any size, throughout the whole life of the fleet, on a secure and easy to use internet-based system. You can use it to track maintenance and inspection for your Mercedes trucks, as well as instantly accessing all documentation at any time of the day or night without needing to wait for it to be posted. You can also use Truckfile to reduce paperwork, streamline admin processes, store your data securely and keep fully up-to-date with all safety requirements within the fleet.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz to supply 2,600 school buses for Brazilian training programme
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes-Benz do Brasil, the Brazilian arm of the Daimler-owned auto manufacturer Mercedes-Benz, has confirmed that it will supply a total of 2,600 school buses to the Brazilian Ministry of Education for a new training programme.
The order is for 2,600 OF1519 R Chassis buses, which will be assembled as school buses and delivered in full during the coming year. Once delivered, the buses will be used as part of training programmes.
A specification for the order was for rugged, high performance vehicles capable of handling rough road conditions in rural areas. Mercedes-Benz buses were chosen because, like other Mercedes trucks and vans, they are highly reliable on a range of road surfaces. The OF1519 R Chassis buses, in particular, are designed for off-road conditions. The model was even named the "Bus of the Year" for Brazil in the 2012 AutoData Awards.
Mercedes-Benz do Brasil has delivered many other vehicles to the Brazilian government over the last few years. Previous orders have included 1,700 Mercedes Atego trucks delivered to the Ministry of Defence and 400 Mercedes Sprinter vans supplied to the Health Ministry of Brazil for use as ambulances.

item.title: Mercedes Actros commissioned by Essex Police
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes Actros truck has reportedly been commissioned by police in Essex as part of its covert patrols on roads in the area. Sitting alongside the Essex Police force’s existing fleet of cars and vans, the Actros is being used as a mobile operations base. It is also being uses at exhibitions, providing the force with great value for money. The main benefit of using the Actros truck to patrol the county’s roads, according to the police, is the height of its cab. By elevating officers above the height of other road users, the police are able to into other trucks and lorries and down into cars. This allows them to spot illegal and potentially dangerous driving practices. The Actros has also already had its first success story, as the police were able to use it to catch a motorist who was using an Apple iPad device on his lap whilst driving. Officers say that without the new viewing angles enabled by the Mercedes Actros, they would never have seen the dangerous and illegal behaviour. Commenting on the iPad incident, PC Gary Winfield said:
"He [the driver] was using it at 56mph on a dual carriageway," "It is frightening really."

item.title: South African logistics company trials Canter Eco-Hybrid truck
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A logistics company operating in South Africa is to test out the Fuso Canter Eco-Hybrid truck for three months, to see if it is a good fit for the business. Imperial Logistics, which describes itself as a “diversified industrial services and retail group with activities spanning logistics; car rental; tourism; financial services; vehicle distribution and retail; automotive parts and industrial products distribution”, has ordered the Canter Eco-Hybrid truck from Mercedes-Benz South Africa. The company will now use the truck as part of normal applications for three months, after which time it may even order more vehicles for its fleet. The Mercedes trucks supplier debuted the light-duty truck at the Johannesburg International Motor Show in 2010. At the time, Godfrey Hani, the divisional manager of MBSA Freightliner, Fuso and Western Star, said of the new vehicle:
“For the Fuso stable and MBSA as a whole, this represents an advance in our quest to play a leading role in the field of green innovation and cements our commitment to sustainable mobility solutions,”
The Fuso Canter Eco-Hybrid has many impressive specifications, including: •Fuso two-pedal Inomat automated mechanical transmission •23 kW electric motor, which doubles as a generator to recharge the lithium-ion battery pack during braking Compared to the Fuso Canter, the Eco-Hybrid version also uses up to 30 per cent less fuel and produces up to 30 per cent less carbon dioxide emissions.

item.title: Why preventative maintenance is the key to an efficient fleet
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: Downtime is the number one enemy of an efficient and profitable fleet, which is why fleet managers should be doing everything they can to avoid it. Implementing a preventative maintenance program is the best way to minimise downtime, as well as keeping repair costs down and efficiency levels up. To put a good preventative maintenance scheme in place, you will need to start by focusing on a few key areas. These include: •Going over your fleet maintenance records. You need to be tracking the right information, and getting enough of it, in order to make informed decisions about your fleet. Remember – you not only need to record the information; you need to be analysing it properly too. •Find the cause of emergency maintenance incidents, where repairs were needed in between scheduled maintenance. You should be looking for trends, as well as the different problems which affect different vehicles. This will help you tailor your new preventative maintenance program to all vehicles in your fleet. •To properly schedule maintenance, look at how many times a year your fleet vehicles are maintained. You may have only scheduled three maintenance visits, but end up needing six because of emergency maintenance. This is closer to the number of visits your vehicles should be having. •Don’t schedule preventative maintenance appointments too close together - what is right for one type of vehicle may not be right for another. For example, if you have both Mercedes vans and trucks in your fleet, each will have different maintenance needs.

item.title: Recycling specialist delighted with its first Mercedes Actros
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Recycling specialist London & Kent Metals has taken delivery of its very first heavy Mercedes Actros truck, which is also the first multi-wheeler vehicle the company has used with an automatic gearbox. London & Kent Metals, an operator based in Sittingbourne in Kent, is delighted with its new acquisition, which was supplied by Sparshatts of Kent. The Actros truck, an 8x4 Actros 3241K with an 410hp output and a 12-speed PowerShift 2 transmission (an optional automatic alternative to the standard 16-speed manual transmission system), has now been fitted out in the company colours. The Actros will join the family-owned company’s existing fleet of tractor units, multi-wheeled hook loaders, skip vehicles and car transporters with slidebed bodies. Two of these car transporters are Mercedes Atego trucks. Commercial director Ryan Eastwood is already delighted with the Actros, explaining:
"These are still early days but the Actros is definitely more economical on fuel than our other roll on-roll offs too. "My lorries are the face of the company when they're out on the road, so I like them to look good too. Not only is the Actros as solid and well-built as you'd expect of a Mercedes-Benz, it's also very smart and great for our image."
The company is also planning to order its first Mercedes tractor unit, a 6x2 New Actros 2551 with tipping hydraulics, a BigSpace cab and a 510hp engine.

item.title: Daimler and Mercedes join ‘Clean Diesel’ campaign
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
Daimler AG, which owns the Mercedes-Benz brand and manufacturers Mercedes trucks, vans and cars, has joined together with other auto manufacturers to back the ‘Clean Diesel, Clearly Better’ campaign.
The campaign, which has been developed by the German Association of Automotive Industry and its 600-strong list of manufacturer and corporate members, aims to inform the US population of the benefits of using ‘clean’ diesel fuel. It has also been set up to advertise the benefits of diesel over gasoline, particularly in terms of cleanliness, consumption and performance.
The campaign has been developed as a multi-brand information platform, with other backers including Audi, BMW, Porsche and Volkswagen as well as Daimler. The participating companies will now display the campaign’s logo on new vehicles, so that customers will know that any vehicle bearing the ‘Clean Diesel’ logo meet the strictest environmental standards. The car makers will also use the logo in their TV spots, brochures, advertisements and in vehicle showrooms.
The official launch of the ‘Clean Diesel, Clearly Better’ campaign is in January 2013, and it will take place at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Michigan.

item.title: Choosing the right body style for your new Sprinter van
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: The Mercedes Sprinter van is one of the manufacturer’s most popular vans and one of the reasons for its popularity is its versatility. As well as being designed to adapt to many different applications and uses, Sprinter vans can also be customised to suit your specific needs. One of the main choices you will need to make when buying a new Mercedes Sprinter van is which body style to go for. Unlike other Mercedes vans which have two options to choose from, the Sprinter has a total of four different body styles available. These are: •Panel Van – available in a choice of 3 load compartment heights and 4 different lengths, the Sprinter Panel Van has spacious interiors and is perfect for delivery and distribution. It is also known as ‘the professional’s van’. •Traveliner – the Sprinter Traveliner is designed for passengers as well as goods, as it can seat up to 17 people and has vastly spacious and comfortable interiors. •Dropside – available in a range of weight variants, vehicle lengths, cab type, load area and payload weight, the Sprinter Dropside is one of the most versatile Mercedes vans. It also excels when it comes to manoeuvring, as well as cruising. •Chassis Cab – the Sprinter Chassis cab is hugely adaptable to a range of different applications, with a strong frame and a high weight capacity. It also comes in three lengths and with extensive safety equipment.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz UK celebrates record sales
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes-Benz UK, the British division of the manufacturer’s international operations, has achieved record figures for new car sales for this year. According to figures released by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), the Mercedes vans, trucks and cars manufacturer nabbed a 4.5 per cent new car registration market share for the year-to-date. The vehicles which led the gain in market share were the Mercedes Coupe, C-Class Saloon, B-Class, Viano people carrier, SLK Roadster and Estate. All of these vehicles achieved record registrations this year. Also performing well this year were the company’s commercial vehicles. The president and CEO of Mercedes-Benz UK, Marcus Breitschwerdt, commented on the success of Mercedes trucks and vans in 2012. He said:
“The commercial vehicle range is very strong in a hard-fought market. The new Actros is building up a substantial and loyal following while van sales are on course to finish 2012 in style with record registrations.”
In fact, the new Mercedes Actros was one of the company’s best performers in terms of sales. Sales of the Actros rose by 38.4 per cent this year, and the figures increased by 26.3 per cent in November 2012 alone.

item.title: Why every fleet should use fuel cards
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: These days, virtually every large fleet uses fuel cards, but some fleet managers still insist on using credit cards to pay for fuel. There are many reasons why fuel cards trump credit cards, which is why any company with a fleet of more than a handful of vehicles should be using them. Fuel card benefits Amongst the many benefits fuel cards can offer fleet managers are the following: •Reduced administration and paperwork •Comprehensive fleet management reporting – managers can receive real-time reports about all aspects of fleet fuel usage and requirements •Increased control for managers, allowing them to set purchase controls with their cards and better manage business expenditure •Competitive fuel prices •No need for drivers to carry cash with them, which also helps to prevent fraud as well as making drivers feel more secure •Improved security, as fuel cards use chip and pin technology •Online account management •Nationwide networks, leading to convenient access •Improved cash flow •Ability to choose from multiple providers and different types of fuel cards to suit the business. For example, managers of fleets of Mercedes trucks and vans may choose a different fuel card provider or plan compared to other makes and models of vehicles. •Points and reward schemes •Easier invoicing

item.title: Is the Vario the van for your business?
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: The Mercedes Vario isn’t like other Mercedes vans, as it is a specialist vehicle that is part truck and part van. It also has a unique design, which makes it suitable for some applications and for some users more than others. The question is – is the Mercedes Vario van right for your business? To help you choose your ideal Mercedes van, let’s take a closer look at some of the Vario’s main features and benefits. Structure The Mercedes Vario is unique in that it has almost vertical sides and a box-like structure. This offers users an ideal interior in which to mount racking, fittings or equipment. Another benefit of this structure is that is maximises interior space. Modular design The design of the Mercedes Vario van is modular, which means that the vehicle can be adapted and customised to meet the specialist needs of virtually any business. Customisable The Vario can be customised in a few ways, to help it suit your needs. It offers a choice of: •Body styles – choose from Panel Van or Chassis cab •Payload limits •Vehicle lengths •Roof heights •Cargo volumes and weight capacities •Equipment

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter put to work as mobile library
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The highly versatile Mercedes Sprinter van is capable of a huge range of different uses, from life-saving ambulances to passenger-friendly tour buses. A council in New Zealand, however, has found a brand new use for the Sprinter – a mobile library. Once funding for the Sprinter van was secured by Southland District Council, an authority in the South Island of New Zealand, the vehicle was bought and kitted out as a mobile library. It will now be used to take books to readers in rural and far-flung parts of the area, as well as being used as a mobile office for ratepayers. Explaining why the council decided to swap a full-size bus for the more compact Sprinter van, District Council library manager Lynda Hodge cited the benefits of improved safety and fuel efficiency. She also said:
"Library usage patterns have changed and it is no longer necessary to carry around a large amount of catalogue in a full-size vehicle, with associated costs and challenges. Reconfiguring the service will enable us to target the items available to customers and there will also be strong promotion of advance ordering through our on-line catalogue,"

item.title: Fleet management tips - minimising fuel usage
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: For fleet managers, keeping fuel costs down is a top priority. There are several ways you can save your business money on fuel costs, such as the measures outlined below.
