Along with 150 teams from 20 countries, the Mercedes teams will travel a total of 2,500 kilometres through Morocco’s desert and into the city of Essaouira, all in the name of raising money for charity. The proceeds of the event will be put towards providing doctors and medical care for people living in isolated parts of southern Morocco.

item.title: Daimler opens new Mercedes vans development centre in China
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The German company Daimler AG, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, has announced that it has opened a brand new product development centre in China. Costing around €60 million (£50,574,060) to build, equip and staff, the new centre is to be used to develop new Mercedes vans for China and other markets. The centre, based in Fuzhou in China, is the first facility to be opened by Mercedes-Benz vans outside of Germany, where the company’s headquarters and parent company are based. The head of Mercedes Vans, Volker Mornhinweg, explained why the decision was made to open the new product development centre, saying:
"This allows us to adapt our vans to local customer needs more effectively, and it demonstrates once again that we aim to be the global player among the world's van manufacturers,"
Inside the product development centre, which is a joint venture between Mercedes Vans and Fujian Benz Automotive Corporation, a main producer of vans in China, there will be a number of different departments. Along with a design and computation department, the centre boasts a prototype production department, an endurance testing workshop and several test rigs.

item.title: Missouri ambulance service upgrades fleet with new Sprinter vans
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
A county ambulance service in Central Missouri, in the U.S. has chosen Mercedes Sprinter vans over other similar vehicles in the same class to add to its fleet of life-saving ambulances.
The Mercedes Sprinter van, which is so versatile that it can be adapted to a number of different purposes and applications, was chosen by the Callaway County Ambulance District (CCAD) to add to its existing fleet.
The Board of Directors for the emergency service considered many other vehicles such as the Ford E-Series and F-Series, as well as the Chevrolet 3500 and 4500 series of trucks, before making its decision. However, due to the fuel efficiency of the Sprinter, along with its many other benefits, it was decided that three of the Mercedes vans will be turned into ambulances and ordered for the service over the coming year.
The director of the CCAD, Charles Anderson, noted that the vehicles being replaced by the Sprinters all had more than 100,000 miles on the clock and were costing the district a considerable amount in fuel and maintenance expenses. When compared to Mercedes Sprinter ambulances, six of which are currently being run by the South Howell County Ambulance District, fuel and maintenance costs were around half as much per mile.

item.title: Kenyan transport company adds six new Mercedes Actros trucks to its fleet
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A leading transport company based in Nairobi, Kenya, has ordered six new Mercedes Actros trucks to add to its existing fleet of 70 Mercedes vehicles. The vehicles ordered by Roy Hauliers Limited, which provides transport services across East Africa, are Actros 3340S 6 X 4 prime movers. They were delivered to the company by a representative from the Mercedes Commercial Vehicles Department at DT Dobie, a local vehicle dealer. Present when the Mercedes Actros trucks were delivered was the operations director for Roy Hauliers Ltd, Sarfaraz Yakub, and the drivers who will be using the new trucks. The drivers who will be taking the Actros trucks out on the road were also given training to familiarise them with the new features of the latest Actros. Driver trainer Joe Mungai explained:
“The current Mercedes trucks are very different from those on the roads 20 years ago. The advances in vehicle technology makes it necessary for drivers to familiarize themselves with the latest features. “Trucks cost the owners a great deal of money and the driver needs to understand the vehicle to be able to minimize fuel consumption and wear and tear.”

item.title: Prime Minister visits Mercedes-Benz apprentices
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
As part of National Apprentice Week, which took place last month, the Prime Minister David Cameron paid a special visit to the apprentices working on Mercedes vans, trucks and cars at the Mercedes-Benz Apprentice Academy in Milton Keynes. At the facility, which provides training to young workers to help them on their way to becoming advisors and technicians for Mercedes-Benz, the Prime Minister met a number of the apprentices working on Mercedes trucks, cars and vans. Mr Cameron was also informed about the different programmes being run at the £2.1 million purpose-built facility which lead to NVQ and VRQ qualifications. Following the visit to the Tongwell facility, which has been training apprentices since 1995 and has more than 1,000 graduates, Mr Cameron said:
"I was delighted to visit the Mercedes-Benz Apprentice Academy today to see the excellent facilities, and to meet so many hard working and highly skilled apprentices," "Apprenticeships are at the heart of our mission to rebuild the economy, giving young people the chance to learn a trade and create a truly world class workforce that can compete and thrive in the global race."

item.title: Manchester’s AMB Services tries out the new Mercedes Citan van
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
AMB Services, a pressure-washing equipment supplier based in Manchester, has the use of a brand new Mercedes Citan van for six months after the firm’s owner won a local competition. Alan Bryan, the boss of the industrial cleaning machine agent company, entered a prize draw with a local Mercedes dealer. He was the lucky winner, getting his company six months’ use of a new and improved Citan van absolutely free. After finding out he had won the top prize in the competition, Mr Bryan, who also runs a Mercedes Vito van, said:
"The Citan looks like an excellent vehicle and very well suited to smaller deliveries at locations where access can be very tight," "I'm really looking forward to putting it to work and seeing how well it performs. My first impressions are certainly positive - I was particularly impressed by how smooth and quiet it was on the drive home after collecting it."
The Mercedes Citan van is powered by a fuel-efficient diesel engine, which comes in three different power outputs (75 hp, 90 hp or 110 hp), and it also comes in three different lengths – Compact, Long and Extra Long. The vehicle, which is the manufacturer’s first entry into the small van market, is also packed with clever features.

item.title: Features of the Mercedes Sprinter Traveliner
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: Like many other Mercedes vans, the Sprinter can be customised and configured in a number of different ways depending on what you need it for. You can change everything from the engine size and the body length to the weight capacity and even the interiors of the van. If you need an efficient and reliable van to transport passengers, the Mercedes Sprinter Traveliner is the body type to go for. Here are the essential details you need to know about this people carrier variant of the UK’s most popular van: •Passenger capacity. Although the capacity of Mercedes Sprinter vans depends on which specification you opt for, the Traveliner has room for as many as 16 passengers plus the driver. •Special equipment. Sprinter people carriers can be fitted with any type of special equipment you need, such as wheelchair lifts for example. •Seats. In a Sprinter people carrier or Traveliner, the seats fitted in the interior are supremely comfortable, durable and safe. There is plenty of leg room, and each seat comes with a three-point seat belt. •Engine efficiency. The Sprinter Traveliner has a super-economical 4-cylinder CDI diesel engine, as well as the tried and tested ECO-Start1 engine-start function to save fuel whilst the vehicle is stationary.

item.title: Mercedes gears up for Commercial Vehicle Show 2013
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
In just a few days, some of the biggest and best vehicle manufacturers in the world will be meeting in the Birmingham NEC to show off some of their most exciting new models. One of the stars of the show at the Commercial Vehicle Show 2013, held between 9th and 11th April, looks set to be Mercedes-Benz, as the manufacturer is planning to showcase a brand new product line-up. Amongst the vehicles Mercedes will be putting on display at the NEC are the following: •The new Mercedes Citan van – the striking looking new van with its ground-breaking BlueEFFICIENCY technology displayed at the event in a range of length variants •The Mercedes Vito Effect – a special edition Vito van sharing features with the Vito sport but with a super-efficient new engine •The Mercedes Arocs – the brand’s newest construction vehicle, which Mercedes is hoping will be the star of the event •The new Mercedes Atego – a best-selling vehicle and one of the youngest Mercedes trucks, the Atego is equipped with a brand new Euro VI engine Speaking before the Commercial Vehicle Show, the President and CEO of Mercedes-Benz in the UK, Marcus Breitschwerdt, said:
“At next week’s CV Show we’re showcasing a wealth of new products, showing that Mercedes-Benz is making enormous investments across the range to deliver efficient, safe, cost-effective commercial vehicles for operators that help drive British businesses forward,”

item.title: Teaser of brand new Mercedes Econic 2014 released
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes-Benz has released new ‘spy’ photographs of its upcoming new Mercedes Econic model for 2014, in a series of images depicting the vehicle undergoing extreme weather testing.
Alongside the Mercedes Unimog, which also has a new model coming out next year, the Econic is shown being put through its paces in one of the coldest places on Earth. To ensure it can handle even the harshest of winter weather conditions, the Mercedes truck was taken through an extensive round of tests in Rovaniemi in Finland.
Along with road-clearing tests in Finland, the new Mercedes Econic truck was also pushed to the limit in some of the hottest places in the world. It was recently spotted cleaning up solar panels under the burning sun in Spain.
These latest tests show that the Mercedes-Benz is pulling out all the stops in an effort to make sure that the 2014 Mercedes Econic, as well as the 2014 Mercedes Unimog, is the most enduring and tough truck it has ever made. The new Econic has been designed to perform efficiently and reliably no matter what the weather, and hopefully the results of the tests will prove that the vehicle delivers on its initial promise.

item.title: Limousine firm takes on two new Sprinter vans
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The international limousine company GEM Limousines Worldwide, has added an all-new type of vehicle to its existing fleet – the Mercedes Sprinter van. The company, which specialises in supplying vehicles to corporations all over the world, has recently taken delivery of two new Mercedes Sprinter vans. The Sprinters will now be added to the firm’s expanding fleet, and will be used for a range of different purposes. The ultimate aim of adding the vehicles to the GEM fleet, however, is to help the company stand out from its main competitors. Thanks to the Sprinter’s standing height of 6 foot 4 inches, the new vehicles can provide GEM’s customers with the ultimate in passenger comfort. The vans can comfortably accommodate as many as eight executives on a business trip or travelling to a meeting, but the company, which is both family owned and all-female owned, also plans to market the vehicles as luxury vehicles for a night out. Commenting on the purchase of the new Sprinter vans, GEM’s VP of Marketing, Paula Dellaluna, said:
“We’re always looking for new ways to expand our fleet in a way that will help our customers find what they’re looking for,” “The Mercedes Sprinter van really encompasses the best of both worlds for our clientele.”

item.title: Tips for getting cheaper van fleet insurance
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: If you run a fleet of vans, such as Mercedes Vito vans for example, one of your biggest costs is likely to be insurance. Along with fuel costs, insurance can be a killer for any small firm’s budget. This is why you need to do everything you can to make your insurance premiums cheaper. Follow these tips: •Invest in driver training. From an insurer’s point of view, better trained and more experienced drivers are less likely to have accidents. Simply by investing a relatively small sum in improving the skills of your drivers, your insurance premiums are likely to cost you less and help you to make a considerable saving over time. •Cut your mileage. A high annual mileage can push your fleet insurance premiums up, so you can save money if you cut your mileage. You can do this by reviewing your routes and maybe investing in GPS systems to help your drivers find the shortest and fastest ways to get to their destinations. •Keep reviewing your insurance cover. You may be rewarded for your loyalty if you stick with the same insurer year after year, but you aren’t always guaranteed to get the best deal on the market. To keep costs low, make sure to review your insurance cover and compare it to other deals once a year.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz Arocs & Atego world premieres at Bauma 2013
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
• Arocs – heavy-duty truck developed specifically for the construction sector, with a permissible gross vehicle weight of up to 41 t
  • New Euro VI-compliant Atego for light- and medium-duty operations
  • Arocs Loader transports 8 cubic metres of ready-mixed concrete
  • Arocs Grounder for particularly heavy loads in demanding terrain
  • Eco-friendliest Euro VI-compliant emission control technology now available in the construction sector, too
Mercedes-Benz will be unveiling two new vehicles to the public for the first time at "Bauma 2013", in the guise of the Arocs heavy-duty construction truck and the new Atego which has been developed for the medium-duty segment. The world's largest fair for the construction industry will be opening its doors to international visitors from 53 countries in Munich from 15 to 21 April. Six Arocs configured specifically for heavy-duty construction site transport show what a powerful, robust and efficient construction vehicle looks like in 2013. As such, they are continuing a Mercedes-Benz success story which extends back over more than 110 years in the field of construction vehicles – whereby the Arocs showcases the merits of this lineage in particularly imposing, heavy-duty style. With its high-torque, resilient BlueEfficiency Power engines, spanning an output range from 175 kW (238 hp) to 460 kW (625 hp), and its robust, solid chassis, suspension and frame design, a defining feature of the Arocs is its exceptional load-carrying capacity. And this capacity certainly stands it in good stead in view of the types of use revealed by recent customer surveys, ranging from construction sites (45 percent) at a gross permissible vehicle weight of up to 41 tonnes, through construction materials transportation (30 percent) to concrete transport (15 percent). Specifically in the area of ready-mixed concrete, the Arocs sets the benchmark in its payload-optimised "Loader" variant, with a transport volume of 8 cubic metres. The Arocs Grounder comes up trumps for customers requiring particularly high levels of stability and robustness in off-road use. Assets on the environmental and efficiency fronts are the most eco-friendly emission control technology to date in compliance with Euro VI and a reduction in fuel consumption of up to five percent. The same applies to the equally new Atego for the light- and medium-duty segment. 42 basic model variants ex-factory, four cabs in three lengths, a wealth of different wheelbases and newly developed Euro VI-compliant BlueEfficiency Power engines with four and six cylinders ranging in output from 115 kW (156 hp) to 220 kW (299 hp) – these are the key features of the new Atego range. It is a popular choice in the ancillary building trades, such as roofing, scaffolding or carpentry. For the transportation of building material in difficult terrain, the Atego is also available in all-wheel-drive variants with permanent or manually selectable all-wheel drive. At the smaller end of the range of vehicles for the construction industry, the Mercedes-Benz Citan is on show at Bauma for the first time. The Citan brings small construction crews, tradesmen and materials for construction and finishing work directly to where they are needed – including environmentally sensitive inner-city locations, thanks to its highly efficient and low-emission engines. Like every Mercedes-Benz, the Citan comes with a comprehensive scope of safety equipment, such as ADAPTIVE ESP®, which is able to identify the load situation and adapt intervention by the control system accordingly. Mercedes-Benz's new stars for the construction industry are on display in hall B4 and on the adjoining open-air site of the Munich trade fair centre from 15 to 21 April 2013. With 550,000 square metres of exhibition space, over 3200 exhibitors and some 420,000 visitors expected, Bauma is the largest fair for the construction industry worldwide. It takes place in Munich every three years. To find out more about he Mercedes-Benz Truck range click here or phone 01707 261111

item.title: FleetBoard: Flexible telematics solutions for construction site transport
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
• Transparent processes at and outside the construction site
  • Reduced fuel and communication costs for the Wesling Group
  • Simplification of work for drivers and vehicle coordinators
Construction transport entails diverse challenges. Telematics-assisted internet services help you to meet these demands. Keeping tabs on the fleet at all times results in reduced operating costs and streamlined processes. At the Mercedes-Benz stand, no. 104/204 in hall B4, Daimler FleetBoard is showing how flexible telematics solutions can be deployed to manage transport operations at and outside the construction site. Companies work with FleetBoard Performance Analysis to systematically develop a fuel-efficient and wear-reducing driving style with their professional drivers, cutting costs and boosting motivation in the process. Objective assessment mechanisms ensure the comparability of individual driving performance across all brands, types of operations and model series. Performance Analysis accords due consideration to fuel consumption- and brake-related factors, as well as the operational profile. This means that every driver who spends a large proportion of his time at the wheel on rough terrain or with heavy payloads is assessed in a fair and objective manner. In order to determine the exact fuel consumption while stationary and while on the move, FleetBoard indicates the time spent stationary with the engine running. For the Wesling Group near Hanover, driver training with FleetBoard has spawned a reduction in the average fleet consumption level from 36 to 34 litres per 100 kilometres. The company has been managing transport operations from its own sand and gravel pits with the aid of FleetBoard since 2006. "With FleetBoard we are able to respond to customers' inquiries immediately and our drivers are always en route with maximum efficiency", says Bastian Niggemeier, authorised representative of Wesling.

Practical experience shows just how worthwhile a telematics system is in construction transport: the FleetBoard map view shows the vehicle coordinator the vehicles' positions and the course of the trips at a glance – with time information on activated PTOs, active or inactive engine or ignition. It plans the trips in parallel with its monitoring functions and relays them to the vehicle together with the geo-coded destination and additional information, for display on the permanently installed DispoPilot.guide or the DispoPilot.mobile terminal. The driver loads the destination directly in the navigation system with truck attributes and logs his progress by means of status messages such as start of work, arrival at loading point, waiting times, consignment note number, payload, etc. Illegible daily reports, queries by telephone or incorrect loads are a thing of the past; the driver is guided step by step through the work process. The vehicle coordinator is able to react to weather-induced delays in construction operations without even picking up the telephone. A message appears in the system automatically when trucks leave or enter production plants or construction sites. Comprehensive daily analyses covering working hours and breaks, waiting times, laden and unladen mileage are possible and the statutory documentation and archiving requirements are met. Access to wheel times and rest periods at the touch of a button or fully automated download of the data are possible from the company headquarters, without a company card on board the vehicle.

item.title: New Unimog and new Econic in winter test drives and final tests
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
•   Test drives at minus 30 degrees Celsius on the Arctic Circle
•   Many innovative concepts for even better driving and operating characteristics
•   Important aim of the tests in Finland: economical consumption rates
From 1 January 2014 the new Euro VI emissions standard will come into effect. That is why the next Unimog implement carrier generation, the Unimog extreme off-roader and the new Econic with low-level entrance will be introduced in autumn 2013 with the new Mercedes-Benz BlueTec 6 engines in their established markets. In addition, these three vehicle model series go to the starting line with extensive design innovations to the interior and exterior, as well as innovations concerning driving and operating characteristics. Many components have been adopted from large-scale truck production, such as the new electronics architecture, chassis components, new drive train and control elements. The Econic in particular has become a new vehicle, except for the tried-and-tested cab body. With it, new standards for this unique vehicle concept have been set for municipal transport, refuse collection and short-radius distribution applications. Currently the test vehicles are undergoing the last tests, for example for use in winter road clearing. Once again, this year's winter testing was carried out in Rovaniemi, Finland which is the capital of Lapland on the Arctic Circle. The vehicles had to complete extensive tests not only with regard to handling and driving characteristics but also in terms of ergonomics and comfort. This ensured that the new vehicles with Euro VI technology could cope with sever climatic conditions and extreme requirements, whilst reliably carrying out customers' tasks on a daily basis. Whether clearing snow in the Alps, cleaning solar panels in the extreme heat of Spain, or for a wide variety of different uses in road servicing all year round, there is one thing that a Unimog must guarantee: the unique vehicle concept must perform its tasks reliably, regardless of altitude, temperature or weather conditions. This also goes for the Econic, the innovative and versatile vehicle with low-level entry for all types of waste disposal tasks. Cold starting at minus 30 degrees Celsius For three years now, the Mercedes-Benz engineers have been subjecting the latest generation of Special Trucks fitted with BlueEfficiency Power engines to the toughest of conditions as part of their winter testing programme. Temperatures of down to minus 30 degrees Celsius, snow metres high and icy roads all present a huge challenge for man and machine. On the test ground with its vehicle dynamics and handling course, a turning loop and a forest track, the development team subjected the new vehicle generations to weeks of extremely tough tests. The aim was to optimise the vehicles' function, efficiency, ergonomics and operating comfort. All the trucks were fitted with high-tech measuring equipment, which at times was attached to over 300 measuring points and collected huge amounts of data. For example, this enabled the testers to gather information about the cold-starting performance of the Euro VI engines and the function of the drive train at minus 25 degrees Celsius. Based on the results, the engineers were able to develop additional measures to improve cold start properties down to lower than minus 30 degrees Celsius, for example through auxiliary heating to pre-heat the coolant. The elements of BlueTec-6 technology were also tested: these include the particulate filter, which, in combination with the Mercedes-Benz SCR system, has been in successful use for years, reducing particulate emissions to levels where they can barely be detected. Also tested were the functionality and speedy thawing characteristics of the AdBlue system at temperatures below minus 10 degrees as well as its guaranteed reliability. The most essential aim, however, was that despite all of the measures which permit the vehicles to conform to the Euro VI standard, fuel consumption should remain low. The vehicle testing in Finland didn't just look at technology: the focus was also on handling, safety standards and driver comfort. These elements include reliable, effective heating including a heated windscreen to provide a clear field of vision as quickly as possible. At the end of the test, the engineers depended on this, because the final part of the test was the long journey from Rovaniemi to Arjeplog in Sweden through the ice-cold Scandinavian winter. At the end, Walter Eisele, Head of Production and Development for Mercedes-Benz Special Trucks, and his team were highly satisfied with the results. "It's a very special experience when, after so many months of development, you can drive the new Econic and the new Unimog over long distances in the endurance test and under extreme conditions," said Eisele. Summer testing at 45 degrees Celsius in the shade The vehicles must of course show their worth in summer tests. These are held every year in the hottest months, July and August, at the test centre in the province of Granada in southern Spain. There, among other things the engineers test the vehicles' performance on climbs into the Sierra Nevada up to an altitude of around 2500 metres in extreme heat which can rise to over 45 degrees in the shade, a dry climate, and strong sunshine. Features tested include the functioning of the air-conditioning and cooling systems. "Whereas the winter trials in Finland test the vehicles for their adaptability in extreme cold, in Spain we make sure that heat and different altitudes do not present a problem. This ensures that our customers can rely on our vehicles for all uses and at all times," Walter Eisele summed up the aim of the sophisticated tests.   For more information on the Mercedes-Benz Truck range click here or phone 01707 261111

item.title: New Arrival at Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles Further Strengthens UK Team
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles has a new member in its UK line-up of Fleet Strategic Account Managers with the appointment of Mark Hamilton to the newly created role of Leasing & Strategic Account Manager. Mark joins Mercedes-Benz UK with significant automotive experience, having spent the past eight years with Audi UK as National Key Account Manager and Regional Contract Hire & Leasing Manager as well as a further five years as Regional Manager at Nissan GB Commercial Vehicles. Andrew Lawson, National Fleet Sales Manager, Mercedes-Benz UK, said: “The appointment of Mark is just another demonstration of commitment in the commercial vehicle fleet arena. One of our key focuses in Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles is our ambition to grow within this industry. “We are pleased to welcome Mark to the fleet team - he brings with him a wealth of experience with corporate customers and the contract hire and leasing sector.”

item.title: Fast-growing maintenance firm adds 128 Mercedes vans to its fleet
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A fast-growing maintenance firm which operates throughout the UK has added a total of 128 Mercedes vans to its fleet in the last six months. Sanctuary Maintenance, which is a part of the housing and care provider Sanctuary Group, made the switch to Mercedes-Benz vehicles after new fleet manager Cliff Lewis came in and assessed the costs of running the company’s existing fleet. He said:
"We looked at the suitability for the job and environmental compatibility of several vehicles, as well as maintenance costs, dealer network coverage and residual values," "Mercedes-Benz emerged as the clear winner.”
The company quickly decided to purchase 128 new vans for its fleet, choosing Mercedes Vito vans, Mercedes Citan vans and Mercedes Sprinter vans. All the vehicles come with BlueEFFICIENCY packages to make them as fuel-efficient, cost-efficient and environmentally friendly as possible. Sanctuary Maintenance’s managing director Dennis Evans said: "We strive to ensure that our operation is as clean and environmentally-friendly as possible. The Vito and Sprinter both tick the box as far as our 'green' credentials are concerned, while the feedback from front-line staff now using these vehicles has also been extremely positive."

item.title: Mentor software used to develop new Mercedes Actros truck
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The leading truck and van manufacturer Mercedes-Benz has revealed that it used software from Mentor Graphics in order to develop its flagship truck, the new Mercedes Actros. The New Actros stands apart from other heavy trucks of its kind, as well as other Mercedes trucks, as it uses innovative electronic and electrical systems that are designed to boost the reliability and the safety, as well as the efficiency, of the vehicle. To design these complex systems, Daimler (the company which owns Mercedes-Benz) needed to use sophisticated software. This is why the vehicle maker turned to the Capital software suite by Mentor Graphics, as the senior manager of Mechatronic Engineering at Mercedes Trucks, Wolfgang Appel, explains:
“To develop such an advanced truck requires not only powerful design automation, but also robust design data management,” “Capital was the natural tool choice because it is so strong in these areas, and is designed to be used by large, multi-site organizations.” Daimler noted that Capital’s powerful design lifecycle management, electrical/mechanical data integration, and standardized communication with suppliers were all key contributors to successful development of the Actros’ complex electrical systems.”

item.title: Italian cycle firm chooses Mercedes Vito fans for UK sales reps
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
For its technical sales representatives in the UK, the Italian cycle manufacturer Bianchi has taken delivery of three new Mercedes Vito vans. The company decided on Dualiner models for its new Vito vans as they are known to be the most versatile. There is a second row of seats fitted in the back, allowing the vehicle to carry up to four passengers. However, whenever extra space is needed, the seating can be removed in order to maximise the load space. Bianchi UK, which distributed bicycles to independent retailers all over the country, needs the vans for promoting its products at exhibitions all over the UK and for supporting its retail partners at events and rides, as well as just for distribution. Its sales representatives need vehicles in which to carry cycle models, as well as those which can carry passengers if necessary. Commenting on the decision to use Mercedes Vito vans over other similar vans, Bianchi’s country manager Andrew Griffin said:
“They’re fantastically versatile vehicles,” “For a weekend demonstration event our reps can carry up to 10 fully-built bikes, as well as a three-metre marquee, boxes of catalogues, riding gear and their own overnight kit, and still have room inside to move around. “Then, if necessary, they can deliver as many as 20 packaged bikes to our dealers. And when they’re not working, with all the seats in place, the Vito also serves as comfortable, safe and stylish family transport for our staff.”

item.title: Chiltern Cold Storage chooses New Actros as the flagship for its fleet
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
Chiltern Cold Storage, one of the UK’s leading providers of temperature-controlled storage services, has chosen the new Mercedes Actros truck to be its flagship vehicle. The company, which is currently in the process of expanding and has just completed a major extension to its headquarters in Peterborough, put its New Actros 2545 on the road back in March 2013. Since then, the truck has continued to impress Chiltern Cold Storage’s managing director Paul Jackson, who is particularly pleased about the Actros’ exceptional mpg returns. He said of the 10.8 mpg average the New Actros is returning:
"That's a really good figure," "New Actros has taken truck technology to another dimension, and is as close as you'll get to a future-proof vehicle."
This particular vehicle is performing so well and returning such impressive mpg figures due to one special feature – the Predictive Powertrain Control (PPC). This is a system which uses 3D GPS mapping to read the road ahead, and is then able to control braking, speed and transmission in order to optimise the fuel efficiency of the vehicle. Chiltern acquired two more new Mercedes Actros trucks after its flagship purchase, and the company is expecting to order another four with the fuel-saving PPC feature.

item.title: 10 new Mercedes Axor trucks for Irish manufacturing firm
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Quinn Manufacturing, one of the largest manufacturing companies in Ireland, has purchased 10 new Mercedes Axor trucks. The vehicles will be replacing other Axor vehicles which are now being stood down after several years of service. The company, which is based in Derrylin, County Fermanagh, bought its original Axor trucks back in 2003. Since then, the trucks have collectively covered over a million kilometres. The decision was made to replace them, but fleet operators at Quinn have been so impressed with the quality and reliability of the Mercedes trucks that they are sticking with Axor vehicles. The transport manager at Quinn, John McNally, said:
"The Axor is also an excellent fit for our application," "The cab is well designed, with a tough, easy-to-clean finish. It also manages to combine plenty of interior space for the occasional nights away, with compact exterior dimensions to make their lives easier when delivering to tight-access locations."
In addition to purchasing 10 new Axor 2543 tractor units, the manufacturing company has also decided to add two 6x4 Mercedes Axor 2633 tippers to its fleet. These durable, heavy-duty vehicles will be put to work in the Tarmac and quarries division of the company.

item.title: Maintenance – the only real way to minimise breakdowns within your fleet
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Whatever type or model of vehicle you run as part of your business fleet, whether it’s Mercedes trucks or another brand of heavy good vehicle, you need to make them as efficient and as profitable as possible. This means maximising fuel efficiency and crucially, keeping breakdowns and down-time to a minimum.
The only real way to minimise breakdowns, in addition to choosing vehicles with exceptional reliability levels such as Mercedes vans and trucks, for example, is proper maintenance. Not only do you need a team or company of maintenance engineers that you trust to do a thorough job and go over every inch of every vehicle, but you also need to ensure that maintenance is being carried out regularly.
Many fleet managers now use computer software to keep track of maintenance schedules for all their fleet vehicles. However, you can also sign up to a service contract with a company specialising in the makes and models of vehicles your business runs. As part of such a contract, the maintenance schedule should be closely monitored and you, as the fleet manager, should receive automatic alerts when a service is due.

item.title: A guide to the 5 new safety systems in Mercedes vans
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: In just a few months, drivers, business owners and fleet managers will be able to get hold of Mercedes vans fitted with innovative new safety systems. The company has launched five new safety systems, three of which are world firsts for the commercial van category. But what are these new features and what do they do? Let’s take a look: 1.Highbeam Assist. This new feature automatically switches the van’s high beams on and off depending on when traffic appears ahead, so as to allow drivers to see corners and obstacles more clearly but without dazzling other road users. 2.Collision Prevention Assist. This system alerts the driver when the vehicle gets too close to another moving vehicle on the road ahead, as well as when approaching the end of a queue of traffic. 3.Crosswind Assist. This system is designed to keep vans on course even in high winds, a feature that will be particularly useful for drivers in Mercedes vans with higher roof body types. 4.Blind Spot Assist. This system alerts the van driver of a vehicle in close proximity in the next lane when a lane change is being attempted. 5.Lane Keeping Assist. This system alerts the driver when the van is drifting or unintentionally changing lanes.

item.title: North Wales Police gives Mercedes Vito van to rescue service
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
In order to help the unit to provide a top-notch service, the North Wales Police Force has given the Snowdonia Search and Rescue Team a Mercedes Vito van. The vehicle, which was formerly used as part of the Police’s driving school, was handed over to the team leader of the Search and Rescue Team, Dafydd Griffiths, by Deputy Chief Constable Ian Shannon. When handing over the keys, the police chief said:
“I am delighted to hand over this vehicle to South Snowdonia Search and Rescue Team on behalf of North Wales Police. The team were exceptionally busy during 2012 and were called out more than twice as many times as the previous year. "They have worked tirelessly alongside their colleagues from the other teams as part of the North Wales Mountain Rescue Association and their commitment and skill is second to none. I have no doubt this vehicle will be put to very good use to make North Wales a safer place.”
The Mercedes Vito van, known to be one of the hardiest and most versatile of all Mercedes vans, will now be used by the Search and Rescue team on its callouts.

item.title: Gleaming gold Sprinter van turned into the perfect advertising tool
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes Sprinter van is one of the most versatile and widely used commercial vans on the planet, but one business in Russia has managed to create a whole new look for the vehicle.
The business, a gentlemen’s club based in the centre of Moscow, is using its Mercedes Sprinter van to advertise itself and bring in new customers. Bosses at the business chose an 8-metre long Sprinter with a panel van chassis, a variant that is perfect for advertising and marketing due to all the space available on the sides and back of the van.
The van was then sent to Re-Styling for a complete makeover, where it emerged in gleaming chrome gold wrap. Never before has a Sprinter van been spotted in all-over gold, which is what the business owners were betting on. No one will be forgetting this van in a hurry!
To date, Mercedes Sprinter vans have been used for a huge range of different applications. As well as being spray-painted gold and covered in marketing messages, Sprinter vans have been sent on expeditions into the wild as well as on trips to exhibitions and trade shows. They have also been used as ambulances, mobile libraries and mobile food vehicles. Is there anything the Sprinter can’t do?

item.title: Mercedes Actros 1851 GigaSpace wins Green Truck 2013 award
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes-Benz Actros 1851 GigaSpace has been handed a prestigious new prize, in the form of the Green Truck 2013 award. The award was determined by the editorial teams of both Trucker and VerkehrsRundschau magazines, the staff of whom agreed that the Mercedes Actros truck was the most fuel efficient of the year. Amongst the key criteria used to decide which commercial truck won the lucrative Green Truck 2013 title were: •Fuel consumption •CO2 emissions •Exhaust emission classification •Max payload With all of these factors taken into account, the Mercedes Actros 1851 GigaSpace truck came out on top. The Euro-VI compliant commercial vehicle demonstrated fuel consumption that was nearly a litre less than the next ranked truck, a level of fuel efficiency achieved thanks to the Mercedes-Benz Predictive Powertrain Control (PPC) technology featured in the Actros. Dr. Jörg Zürn, the Head of Truck Product Engineering at Mercedes-Benz, said that the Actros winning the award:
“…provides conclusive, independent confirmation of the results of the development work we have undertaken with the objective of creating a new, environmentally compatible truck that would comply with the Euro VI emissions standard.”

item.title: The New Mercedes-Benz Sprinter: Sets new benchmarks in efficiency, safety and dynamics on the market
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
• World’s first van to meet the future Euro VI emissions standard

  • Most economical van in its class

  • Enhanced exterior and interior

  • World premiere of new safety systems

  • Millions of kilometers of testing; sales to begin in June

The Mercedes-Benz Sprinter has lent its name to an entire vehicle segment and is a synonym for large vans all around the globe. The Sprinter has always driven innovations in its segment — a tradition that is being continued by the new model. The new Sprinter continues to set standards, boasting five new safety systems, engines that meet the future Euro VI emissions standard, and a striking new appearance. Most importantly, however, the van’s excellent low fuel consumption of 44.4 mpg makes it the most efficient vehicle in its segment.

World premiere of new safety systems

The Sprinter has always been a pioneer with regard to driver assistance systems. Five new assistance systems — including several van firsts — will help reduce the number of accidents even further in the new Sprinter. The following systems are celebrating their world debut in the Sprinter: Crosswind Assist, which is fitted as standard, and COLLISION PREVENTION ASSIST and Blind Spot Assist, which are both optional. Other new features are Highbeam Assist and Lane Keeping Assist. The developers at Mercedes-Benz are convinced that these electronic assistants will play a key role in helping to reduce accidents in the van sector. As one of the functions of the Electronic Stability Program, Crosswind Assist will be part of the vehicle’s range of standard equipment. Customers will be able to order the other assistance systems as individual options or as components of logically assembled packages. This allows every customer to tailor the Sprinter to their specific area of application. In addition, Mercedes-Benz has improved the Sprinter’s handling even further. The lowering of the chassis has improved the van’s drag and fuel consumption and makes it easier to load and unload cargo.  

World’s first van to meet the future Euro VI emissions standard

The new Sprinter is the world’s first van to meet the future Euro VI emissions standard in all of its engine variants. Euro VI drastically reduces the emission limits for nitrogen oxides (NOx), total hydrocarbons (THC), and particulate mass. The Sprinter achieves the strict limits with the help of its BlueTEC engine and SCR technology that injects AdBlue into the exhaust gas. The technology has already proven its worth in more than 100,000 commercial vehicles from Mercedes-Benz. The performance of the diesel engines has remained unchanged, encompassing four- and six-cylinder units with outputs ranging from 95 hp (70 kW) to 190 hp (140 kW). The developers have used the additional exhaust treatment stage to optimise the injection and combustion processes as well as the boost pressure. The results are lower fuel consumption and less combustion noise. The engineers also adjusted the drive system and the ancillary components to enhance fuel efficiency. This applies to the transmission and the rear axle as well as an intelligent generator management system. As an alternative to the diesel engines, the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter is also available with a Euro VI compliant supercharged four-cylinder natural gas engine featuring direct injection. The engine generates 156 hp (115 kW) from a total displacement of 1.8-litres. Power is transmitted either by the ECO-Gear six-speed manual transmission or the 7G-TRONIC PLUS seven-speed automatic transmission with lock-up clutch, which is the only system of its kind to be found in a van.  

Most economical van in its class

The combination of the highly efficient diesel engines, the optimised powertrain, the longer axle ratio, the ancillary components, and the BlueEFFICIENCY PLUS efficiency package has reduced fuel consumption to a minimum of 44.4 mpg (NEDC combined), which is a record value for the Sprinter segment. However, the new Sprinter is extremely economical not only as a result of its high fuel efficiency, but also because it comes with the ASSYST maintenance calculation system as standard in Europe. Thanks to this system, the van’s maintenance intervals, which were already long, have been extended to up to 37,000 miles.  

Enhanced exterior and interior

The new Sprinter’s appearance has also been substantially enhanced and made more striking. In line with Mercedes-Benz’ current design, the van’s radiator grille is now more vertical and confident. The grille’s three slats are perforated and wedge-shaped. Not only does this change create a more dynamic impression, it also increases the airflow. In addition, a frame surrounds the brand’s distinctive radiator grille, making it more prominent. Another change involves the headlights, which are now more angular. The covers on the reflector housings are particularly striking, dividing the headlights into separate segments. The new hood is higher and the more distinctly shaped bumpers have finely worked lower edges similar to those found on SUVs. The new Sprinter is immediately recognisable from the rear, due to its double-segmented taillights. The widely acknowledged exemplary interior has also been further enhanced. Comfort has been boosted by the new upholstery and seat coverings, the thicker steering wheel makes gripping easier, and the fresh air nozzles boast chrome applications if the customer opts for a multifunctional steering wheel. The knob of the gearshift lever has been redesigned as well. The Sprinter is also fitted with a new-generation radio system that equips the van not only with state-of-the-art electronic entertainment features and Bluetooth telephone equipment (including a telephone keypad and phonebook), but also the Becker MAP PILOT navigation system.  

Millions of miles of testing; sales to begin in June 2013

The developers of the new Sprinter made sure that the van was thoroughly tested. More than five million miles of endurance testing and extensive customer trials in everyday use had fully demonstrated the new Sprinter’s high quality by the time series production was launched.   Customers can order the new Mercedes-Benz Sprinter beginning in June 2013; deliveries will commence in September.  For more information contact S & B Commercials on 01707 261111

item.title: Survey finds SME fleet managers are gradually going greener
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A recent survey carried out by a fleet funding specialist Alphabet has found that small businesses are increasingly choosing greener vehicles for their fleets, but also that many are still concerned about the cost of going green. The research, carried out as part of the Alphabet Fleet Management Report (AFM) 2012, found that the number of organisations setting themselves green targets is on the rise. In 2011, just 45 per cent were committed to environmental goals, but this jumped to a massive 79 per cent in 2012. The year-on-year fleet management survey also found, however, that many fleet managers are still concerned about how much it costs to go green. Just over half of the fleet managers included in the survey named cost as the main barrier to reaching green goals, despite the fact that many new vehicles, including Mercedes trucks and vans, offer super-efficient systems and features included in the price. The sales and marketing director at Alphabet, Paul Hollick, explained how fleet managers should be thinking about the cost of going green, saying:
“SMEs should also consider switching to Whole Life Cost calculations, as opposed to lease-cost-based choice lists, as a more effective means of identifying real costs and when cars should be changed. Think in three or four year ‘blocks’ rather than focusing on first-year savings.”

item.title: The new Mercedes Sprinter – what to expect
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: The brand new and improved Mercedes Sprinter van is finally here, but what can we expect to see in the new model? In short, what’s new? Since the Mercedes Sprinter was first launched back in 1995, it has sold more than 2.5 million and has become one of the most popular commercial vans of its kind. This is not a formula that Mercedes wanted to mess with too much, which is why the new Sprinter vans will have the same power output, as well as the same principal chassis design. The new Sprinter will be just as versatile, user-friendly, great-looking and customisable. New features Whilst hanging on to the fundamental features and build quality that made the Sprinter so popular in the first place, Mercedes has also added a huge number of new features, improvements and enhancements. For example, the new Sprinter boasts: •Euro-6 emissions standard engines, capable of optimum fuel efficiency •Enhanced exterior – including a repositioned radiator grille, redesigned headlights and re-shaped bumpers •Enhanced interiors – including new trim options, seat coverings and the very latest radio and Bluetooth system •Brand new safety systems (many of which are world firsts)– including Crosswind Assist, Lane Keeping Assist and Collision Prevention Assist.

item.title: Lighting specialist adds Mercedes Citan vans to its fleet
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Litenow, the commercial lighting specialist operating in many parts of the UK, has chosen Mercedes Citan vans as the latest additions to its fleet. The company, which covers the South East and London from its Reading headquarters but also has an office in Bristol, specialises in using the latest technology to provide its customers with comprehensive outdoor and indoor lighting services. To help the company meet its customers’ needs, as well as meeting green targets and keeping costs down, Litenow has selected the Mercedes Citan van as its vehicle of choice. It has ordered three Mercedes Citan vans to add to its fleet, all of which come with innovative fuel-saving BlueEFFICIENCY packages. These packages offer eco-friendly and energy-efficient features such as the ECO start/stop function, battery management systems and market-leading mpg figures. Commenting on the decision to add Mercedes Citan vans to its existing fleet, Litenow’s managing director Steve Hiscox said:
"We were looking for a vehicle that would complement our company's ethos of energy use reduction and the Citan BlueEFFICIENCY does just that. "We ran a Mercedes-Benz Vito van for a couple of years and it was a first-rate vehicle, but just too big for our needs. The Citan, by contrast, is the perfect size for the job. It can carry all of the tools and equipment our engineers need - we hire in specialist access equipment when necessary - but is very economical to operate, particularly in London where we have a lot of customers."

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter wins U.S. ‘Best Fleet Value’ award
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes Sprinter van has been honoured with a prestigious prize, the Vincentric award for the ‘Best Fleet Value in America’, for the second year in a row. Vincentric, which specialises in providing data, insight and knowledge to the automotive industry, analysed more than 3,400 vehicle configurations to determine the winner of the award. It ran 20 different lifecycle cost scenarios, using multiple factors such as financing, fuel, maintenance, depreciation, taxes, fees, repairs, insurance and fuel to work out which was the best value vehicle for companies running fleets. The ultimate winner and the vehicle named the ‘2013 Best Fleet Value in America’ was the Mercedes Sprinter van, which also happened to win the award the previous year. Commenting on the win, the General Manager of Commercial Vans for Mercedes-Benz USA, Claus Tritt, said:
"Winning the Vincentric Best Fleet Value in America award for the second time in a row for our 3/4 Ton Passenger Van, 3/4 Ton Full Size Cargo Van, and 1 Ton Full Size Cargo Van is confirmation that owning a Mercedes-Benz Sprinter will provide the most compelling real-world cost of ownership to our valued customers,"
The award is likely to give the already popular Sprinter van a further boost, paving the way for the launch of the brand new Mercedes Sprinter van this year.

item.title: Fleet insurance FAQs answered
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: A fleet manager’s job is not an easy one, with a considerable number of costs and tasks to juggle at any one time. After fuel costs, insurance is one of the biggest expenses a fleet will incur, and fleet managers need all the information at their fingertips if they are to get the right insurance for their fleet and to keep costs down. The following are some of the most commonly asked questions relating to fleet insurance, along with their answers: 1.Will driver training lower fleet insurance premiums? Whilst it may not make a difference to immediate quotes a fleet manager gets for insurance, investment in driver training will reduce insurance premiums significantly over a longer period of time, as it allows the company to reduce accident claims and build up a long-standing safety record. 2.How much does the vehicle affect insurance premiums? Experts agree that the type of vehicles in your fleet will affect insurance premiums, with factors such as engine size and category playing a significant role. It may also be the case that vehicles with excellent safety records and safety controls, such as the new range of Mercedes vans and trucks, for example, will help to lower fleet insurance premiums. 3.Can I insure all fleet vehicles under one policy? Unlike other sectors, business fleets only have a limited number of choices when it comes to insurance. This makes it easier to choose a policy and in many cases, you can insure a range of trucks, vans and cars under a single policy.

item.title: Potter Logistics signs up for 10 new Mercedes Actros trucks
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A logistics firm known for its warehouse, distribution and rail freight terminal services is taking steps to grow its transport sector by adding 10 new Mercedes Actros trucks to its existing fleet. Potter Logistics, which has a distribution centre in York along with several other bases, has selected Actros 2545 tractor units to add to its fleet, along with 22 trailers which are a mix of single and double decks. Nick Brightey, the general manager of the transport division for Potter Logistics, is confident that the significant investment the company has made in the top quality Mercedes trucks will pay off. Speaking to Materials Handling World magazine, he said:
"Investing in these premium trucks and trailers demonstrates our continuing commitment to further improve the quality of Potter's transport and distribution service to its customers. "The Actros 2545 truck is our new fleet vehicle of choice. After a trial period we opted for the Mercedes for several reasons - they are reliable trucks with superior fuel economy, minimal running costs and a lower level of depreciation than the competition. We're sufficiently pleased with the trucks that we've put in an order for eight more.”

item.title: New Euro VI compliant Econic to join clean-running new Sprinter
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
There have been a lot of exciting announcements from Mercedes-Benz recently, including the news that a brand new Mercedes Econic truck is on the way.
Mercedes revealed recently that it is planning a late 2013 launch for its new Econic truck, as well as announcing a complete update of its tough, multi-purpose unit, the Mercedes Unimog. The 2014 Mercedes Econic is set to be stronger and more efficient than its predecessors, as well as being easier to operate. However, one of the most exciting developments will be in the vehicle’s engine, which will be Euro VI- compliant.
The company has already managed to meet Euro VI emissions targets in its newest commercial vehicle release, the brand new Mercedes Sprinter, which became the very first van to officially meet the standard. The new Econic is now set to join it, boasting maximum fuel efficiency and a cleaner running engine.
New Mercedes Econic trucks will borrow a lot of the features from the Mercedes Actros, including the electronics and chassis. The new and improved models will also have reduced fuel consumption and lower repair and maintenance costs, which will be music to fleet manager’s ears.

item.title: New Actros wins out in Staplehurst Transit evaluation exercise
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
After carrying out an intensive round of evaluation exercises and comparisons, the family-owned transport company Staplehurst Transits has chosen the new Mercedes Actros truck to join its fleet. The company, which is based in Kent, had been running trucks from a Swedish manufacturer for the last 25 years. Bosses decided to break with tradition after realising that they could get better performance and importantly, better miles per gallon, with a different manufacturer. The Mercedes Actros managed to beat out the competition in Staplehurst’s evaluation exercises and the company decided to order a New Actros 2551 unit with an aerodynamic StreamSpace cab and Daimler FleetBoard telematics system. Delighted with the purchase is company director Darren Goldup, who said of the New Actros:
"I've driven it myself and it's definitely smoother and more comfortable than our established trucks, while the automated PowerShift transmission is very good too," "The fleet average is between 9.1 and 9.2mpg, and, despite the fact that it's still very new and not properly loosened up yet, the New Actros is already hitting 8.9mpg. "This compares well with a unit from our other supplier, which went on the road at the same time as the Mercedes. That vehicle is on similar work, but lagging behind at 8.5mpg."

item.title: Safety charity urges fleets to be more aware of blind spots
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The road safety charity Brake is urging fleets to be more aware of the importance of checking blind spots, as it is vital to preventing collisions and crashes with pedestrians and cyclists.
Brake has revealed that around 13 per cent of collisions with cyclists involve commercials vehicles. Of these, around 16 per cent result in serious injury or loss of life. Furthermore, it has been discovered that up to a third of drivers will experience psychological problems potentially lasting as long as a year after they have been involved in a road traffic accident.
Brake is planning to hold seminars on the subject in Birmingham this May, where the main causes of collisions with vulnerable road users will be highlighted and discussed. The charity is also trying to raise awareness of the importance of checking blind spots, especially when reversing in a commercial vehicle.
As well as increasing training for fleet drivers on the subject of blind spots, fleet managers should also consider using vehicles equipped with on-board technology to check blind spots and help drivers avoid collisions. The new Mercedes Sprinter van, for example, along with a range of other new Mercedes trucks and vans, come with a safety feature called Blind Spot Assist. This gives off a warning when a driver is attempting to change lanes and another vehicle or object is dangerously close.

item.title: All-new Citan vans play starring role in Brighton Marathon
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
At the recent Brighton Marathon, in which new course records were set by two runners, a noticeable presence at the side of the course was a fleet of brightly coloured Mercedes Citan vans.
The Citan vans, which had been painted a memorable bright orange colour, were at the marathon acting as promotional vehicles for a local dealer. One had the important job of bearing the race timing board, whilst the other was on static display just before the finish line, at the sea front.
A third Citan van, in a larger variant, was tasked with leading a procession of motorcycles and scooters through the town, assisted by a Mercedes Vito van. The cavalcade was designed to evoke the ‘mods and rockers’ heritage of Brighton, and it attracted huge crowds on the day.
Alongside the Citan vans and Vito vehicle was a fleet of 17-seater Mercedes Sprinter vans. The vehicles, which were Traveliner minibuses, were used to collect VIP guests and athletes from Gatwick airport. Meanwhile, further demonstrating just how versatile the range of Mercedes vans really is, a company of Sprinter 4x4 vans and Fuso Canter curtainsiders were on the scene to provide logistical support.

item.title: Network Rail signals its clean, ‘green’ ethos with zero-emission Mercedes-Benz Vito E-CELLs
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Employees of Network Rail are now being ferried between the company’s flagship Westwood residential leadership development centre and the local railway station in a pair of fully-electric Mercedes-Benz minibuses that produce no pollutant emissions whatsoever. The eight-seat Vito E-CELL Traveliners are driven by the concierge team, who make dozens of journeys each day from Westwood, on the outskirts ofCoventry, to the Tile Hill railway station less than a mile away. Network Rail operatesBritain’s railway infrastructure, as well as running 17 key stations. Its investment in the ground-breaking Vito E-CELL underlines the company’s commitment to environmental responsibility. Head of Westwood David Williams explains: “Rail is a very ‘green’ form of transport and we were keen to reflect this in the vehicles we use to collect our guests from the local station and return them at the end of their stay with us. “We’re very proud of our new Mercedes, which tick all the boxes from an environmental standpoint. They are also a pleasure for the team to drive and have been exceptionally well received by delegates attending professional skills development courses, graduate training programmes and leadership conferences here at Westwood.”

  The factory-built minibuses were commissioned after a year-long evaluation exercise led by Steve Duffy, Network Rail’s Business Support Manager, National Delivery Service, who worked closely throughout with members of the concierge team at Westwood. The E-CELLS wear eye-catching liveries proclaiming their zero-emission credentials and, when not in use, take pride of place at the front of the impressive building, parked alongside pillars on which charging points have been installed. Also available as a panel van, the Vito E-CELL is the world’s first battery-powered light commercial vehicle to be built on line at a mainstream production facility. An 82 hp (60 kW) electric motor drives the front wheels, which means that the space beneath the load floor can be used to store the lithium-ion batteries without impinging on the passenger or cargo area. The whisper-quiet E-CELL also employs a regenerative system which captures the energy that would otherwise be lost in braking. As well as increasing range, this is used to power the heating and ventilation system and standard-fit heated seats, making the vehicle suitable for use on the coldest of days. Steve Duffy recalls: “The decision to invest in these vehicles was not taken lightly. The journey began a year ago, when we visited the Mercedes-Benz stand at the Commercial Vehicle Show. Since then we have undertaken a great deal of research and evaluation, considering all sorts of alternatively fuelled vehicles, and undertaken several trials, before finally coming down in favour of an all-electric solution in the shape of the Vito E-CELL. “It’s a fantastic piece of kit and meets all of our targets in terms of sustainability, so I’d like to think that before long we’ll have more electric Vito models in service in other parts of our business.” And he adds: “Mercedes-Benz has handled our account in an exemplary fashion. Nothing has been too much trouble for the sales team, who have been very helpful but never pushy, while the manufacturer’s technical specialist has also provided first class advice and assistance. They are all a credit to the organisation.”

 The Vito E-CELL is free from Congestion Charge and VED fees and offers volume and payload capacities which are in line with those of standard models. The vehicle will cover an average of 80 miles between recharges – to maximise operating range, it has an electronically limited top speed of 56 mph. A completely empty battery can be recharged from a 380/400 volt input in a maximum of six hours. Charging is quick and entirely safe, as the smart cable cannot be removed during charging, nor the vehicle driven off while it is attached. The Mercedes-Benz Vito E-CELL is every bit as safe as standard Vito models, with the latest Adaptive ESP® anti-skid system and dual airbags both standard. The batteries are protected by a shock element and should a collision occur the high-tech voltage network is switched off when the airbag control unit activates.   For more information on the Mercedes-Benz Vito contact our Van Sales Executives on 01707 261111, or visit our website.

item.title: LJA Miers delighted with great value New Actros
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
After taking delivery of a brand new Mercedes Actros truck, the rubber and plastics manufacturing and supply specialist LJA Miers has reported that it is delighted with its new acquisition. The New Actros, an 18-tonne 1842 model with a BigSpace cab, was bought to replace a similar vehicle which had come to the end of its time with LJA Miers. The company found that not only was it cheaper to buy the New Actros compared to buying a similar vehicle from the brand it will be replacing, but it will also be cheaper to run, maintain and repair. Managing director of the Cambridgeshire-based company, Andrew Miers said:
"Our last vehicle returned 12 mpg, which we thought was good. But the New Actros has recorded 14 mpg, which represents a very significant saving, especially given that it covers a lot of miles. "Its purchase price was also lower than the latest version of the truck we'd used previously, as are the r&m costs. Combine those two factors with the savings we're making on fuel and it's easy to see why we're so pleased with the latest addition to our fleet."

item.title: Mercedes Arocs teams up with Thompsons for Tip-ex 2013
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
At this month’s Tip-ex show, held between 30th May and 1st June, attendees can expect to see an exciting new partnership forming. Mercedes-Benz will be teaming up with the Thompsons Group, the UK’s leading bodybuilder, to showcase the first UK exhibition model of the Mercedes Arocs truck with a Thompsons body. The Mercedes Arocs truck, part of the hugely popular range of Mercedes trucks which also includes the New Actros, the Antos and the Atego, has been fitted with a Loadmaster Lite body ready for the show. The body, manufactured by Thompsons, is all steel. The director of The Thompsons Group, Scott Burton, commented on the all-steel body the Arocs will be fitted with, saying:
“We are naturally delighted that Mercedes-Benz chose a Loadmaster body for its first Arocs eight wheeler.”
Tip-ex 2013, the national exhibition specially catering for the tipping industry, will be held at the Harrogate Exhibition Centre with free entry. Attendees wanting to take a look at the Mercedes Arocs with its Thompsons body can find it in Hall A of the Centre until 1st June, and you may also be able to see Thompsons’ Stonemaster, its new maximum payload steel tipper body, which will also be unveiled at Tip-ex.

item.title: Brand new Citan van for security systems specialist
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Sabre Security and RF systems, a specialist in electronic security systems, has taken delivery of a brand new Mercedes Citan van. The company is already so impressed with the model that it has ordered another identical vehicle to add to its fleet. The company, which is based in Chatham, chose a Citan 109 CDI van with a long body and Mercedes-Benz’ pioneering BlueEFFICIENCY package, which boasts a range of features designed to boost fuel efficiency and lower emissions. The new Citan van will be used by Sabre Security’s senior engineer Billy Wells, who will be using it to install and service electronic security systems throughout the South-East. The managing director of the company, Richard Rodgers, has revealed that the Citan isn’t the only Mercedes van run by Sabre Security. His partner Craig also has another Mercedes van, the Vito Sport-X, of which Mr Rodgers said:
"I've always liked Mercedes-Benz vehicles and Craig's Vito is brilliant, combining sporty good looks with the quality, reliability and exemplary safety features for which the brand is renowned," "Unfortunately, though, it's just too big for use by our engineers. A lot of our work is undertaken in and around London, where the heavy traffic means we need vans which are as compact and fuel-efficient as possible. The Citan fits the bill perfectly."

item.title: Fleet managers focusing on productivity, survey finds
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
A new survey has found that the main concern of fleet managers, including the managers of Mercedes trucks and vans fleets, in the UK is productivity and how it can be maximised. The research, carried out by GE Capital Fleet Services, found that 44 per cent of fleet managers included in the survey named maximising productivity as the most important and efficient way to keep running costs down within their fleet. When it comes to the other measures fleet managers see as their top priority, the survey found that 24 per cent are focusing meeting cost savings goals whilst 20 per cent are attempting to understand the impact of new vehicle technologies (i.e. alternative fuel vehicles). When it comes to how fleet managers are maximising productivity, 29 per cent believe that specifying the right vehicle for the job is the most important measure. Also important was reducing downtime (18 per cent) and looking at the total cost of ownership (also 18 per cent). Commenting on this part of the results was Ken Gillies, GE Capital Fleet Services’ manager of truck purchasing and engineering, who said:
“Unexpected downtime can result in lost time and money, and cause unnecessary difficulties for fleet managers and drivers alike,”

item.title: Mercedes Citan scoops Most Popular Van award
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
It may only have been officially launched a couple of months ago, in March 2013, but the new and improved Mercedes Citan is already making its mark. The latest accolade for the Citan van is a prize from the Honestjohn.co.uk awards, where it was named Most Popular Van. The awards, which were held in London recently, were hosted by the car reviews website Honestjohn.co.uk. Users of the recently launched website, which aims to provide car buyers with straightforward advice and reviews on a wide range of models, voted to decide the winners of the awards. Voted Most Popular Van in its category was the Mercedes Citan, which has demonstrated good sales so far in just a couple of months. The editor of the Honestjohn.co.uk website, Dan Harrison, said:
“The review which has stood head and shoulders above the rest when it comes to our users is the new Citan. This is the first ever small van from Mercedes-Benz and it feels a cut above the competition in terms of quality and refinement. It's proved very popular on the site and with the new Sprinter coming soon it looks to be a busy year for Mercedes-Benz vans.”

item.title: Courier company invests in nippy new Citan van
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A courier company based in the Dumfries and Galloway town of Gretna has recently taken delivery of a brand new Mercedes Citan van, after winning six months free use of one and being really impressed with its performance. David Elgey, the proprietor of David Elgey Services, won the free use of a new Citan at a local dealer’s launch event. He was awarded the prize after guessing the mpg figure of the new Citan 109 CDI BlueEFFICIENCY model, which is a remarkable 65.7. After testing out the Citan, Mr Elgey decided to buy one for himself. He has added a Citan 108 CDI Long model to his delivery fleet of 15 vehicles, which also includes a larger Mercedes Vito van and two 3.5 tonne Mercedes Sprinter vans. Speaking of his new purchase, Mr Elgey said:
"Until now I've had to go elsewhere for small vans but the arrival of the Citan has changed all that. These are early days, of course, but it looks to be in a different league from other vehicles in this class in terms of build quality and fuel economy. And it's great to drive too. "It's the perfect size for us, "Most of our work entails carrying relatively small loads over long distances. That means we don't need a large van, and that fuel economy is much more important than payload or size.”

item.title: Logistics firm marks 35th anniversary with new Mercedes trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
A South Wales logistics firm celebrating 35 years in business has decided to celebrate by buying new, fuel-efficient Mercedes trucks, marking its first investments in over two decades. Hicks Logistics, which is based in South Wales but operates all over the UK, has invested in a range of new Mercedes trucks to add to its 60-strong fleet. First up is a new Mercedes Actros truck, bought by Hicks in March 2013. The model is a New Actros 2545 tractor unit with a BigSpace cab and a flat floor, and a 450hp straight-six engine. So impressed was the firm with the first Actros, which has already delivered an extra half mile per gallon compared to other trucks in the family-owned business’ existing fleet, it has ordered another to be delivered soon. Managing director Terry Hicks said:
"It's heavy-duty work which takes us all over the UK," "The fleet average is 8 mpg but the New Actros is already up to 8.5 mpg. These are still early days, though, so there's every reason to think this figure will improve still further as it gets more miles under its belt."
Alongside the New Actros models are five 2544 Long Distance models that Hicks Logistics has ordered from the current Mercedes Actros range.

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter scores double win at 2013 Van Fleet World Honours
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
At the recent 2013 Van Fleet World Honours awards, Mercedes-Benz managed to scoop not one, but two of the top prizes. The van winning the accolades for the manufacturer was the Mercedes Sprinter van, which was named the Best Large Van in the event. It also scooped the overall Safety Award, thanks to its many safety features and impressive safety record. The editor of Van Fleet World, John Kendall, explained the reasons why the Sprinter won the Safety Award in particular, saying:
“Mercedes-Benz was the first van manufacturer to offer Electronic Stability Program on the Sprinter 11 years ago and is the only van manufacturer to fit the safety system as standard to all its vans – Citan, Vito and Sprinter. Later this year, the new Sprinter will be the first to be fitted with Crosswind Assist as standard, to maintain stability in a strong crosswind. Collision Avoidance and Blindspot Assistance will also be available on the new model. Few rivals come close.”
Mercedes-Benz has triumphed at the Van Fleet World event, along with the Fleet World Honours, for five years in a row, winning everything from Most Improved Fleet Manufacturer to Best New Car.

item.title: Rail company makes use of electric Vito E-Cell Traveliners
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A leading rail company has started to use extremely eco-friendly Mercedes Vito E-Cell vans, which make use of innovative technology, to transport its employees where they need to go. Network Rail, which runs 17 important train stations and manages the infrastructure of Britain’s railway networks, bought two fully-electric Mercedes Vito vans for ferrying its employees between local railway stations and its leadership development centre. The E-Cell vans have been ordered in a Traveliner variant, which is suitable for carrying passengers with its eight seats, and they resemble mini buses. The Vito vans produce zero exhaust emissions, which will be very good for Network Rail’s green credentials. Commenting on the use of the electric vehicles, the company’s David Williams said:
"Rail is a very ‘green’ form of transport and we were keen to reflect this in the vehicles we use to collect our guests from the local station and return them at the end of their stay with us. "We’re very proud of our new Mercedes-Benzes, which tick all the boxes from an environmental standpoint. They are also a pleasure for the team to drive and have been exceptionally well received by delegates attending professional skills development courses, graduate training programmes and leadership conferences here at Westwood."

item.title: New Mercedes tractor units for South Wales fleet operator
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Owens Road Services, widely known for being one of the largest fleet operators in South Wales, has made its first investments in Mercedes vehicles in decades, with the latest models from the auto manufacturer seemingly being too good to resist. The company has chosen to spend its hard-earned cash on five new Mercedes Actros trucks. The new vehicles are 2546 models with 460 hp V6 engines, each mated to Mercedes innovative PowerShift 2 automated transmission system. The Actros trucks have flat-floored MegaSpace cabs, so as to make driving conditions very comfortable for the fleet’s drivers.
