The company, which was founded by the Owed brothers back in 1970 and has its headquarters in Llanelli, offers its customers distribution and storage services. It has recently won a prestigious new contract with Amazon.co.uk, which is presumably why the firm’s managers decided that the time was right to purchase the Mercedes Actros trucks. One of the fleet operators’ directors, Eurof Owen, said of the new additions to the fleet:
"We'd seen and heard good things about Actros fuel efficiency so, with diesel costs at the top of the agenda these days, decided to try a couple of demonstrators. Both performed impressively but one did particularly well, returning 9 mpg at 44 tonnes."

item.title: The new Citan van – will you choose Mixto, Panel or Crewbus?
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: As fans of Mercedes vans and other commercial vehicles will know, there is a new addition to the brand’s small van family – the new Mercedes Citan. However, what you might not know is that the new Citan comes in three versatile model variants – so which one will you choose? Panel Citan panel vans come in three lengths – compact, long and extra-long – with the very longest variant being 4.71 metres. The panel variant, like with many other Mercedes vans, is tailor-made for marketing, as it allows you to add your own branding, company and contact details. Mixto If you choose the Citan Mixto, you will be getting a very versatile vehicle indeed. It comes in extra-long, which is 4.71 metres, and it has five seats, a foldable bench seat at the rear and two handy sliding doors for easy access. Crewbus The Citan Crewbus is long, versatile and perfect for passengers. It has a sliding door, five seats and a rear bench seat that can be folded away in case you need to store luggage or goods. Like the other Citan model variants, the Crewbus also comes in three weight variants.

item.title: Sprinter named Panel Van of the Year 2013 by VansA2Z
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Already known as one of the most versatile, hard-working and popular vans in the Mercedes-Benz van family, the Mercedes Sprinter has now received another accolade – an award from VansA2Z. VansA2Z, which provides news, reviews, buyers guides and recommendations for fans and users of commercials vans, has named the Mercedes Sprinter 4x4 van its 4x4 Panel Van of the Year 2013. This four-wheel drive variant of the popular Sprinter model offers drivers a 35:65 split between the front and rear axles. Gear reduction is available too. Like other Sprinter variants, it also offers a choice of diesel engines, although VansA2Z favours the 190hp 3.0-litre V6 engine. Additionally, the 4x4 Sprinter has a marginally higher ground clearance compared to more mainstream variants and it also enviably compact, city-ready and mobile, particularly when compared to some of its closest competitors. Explaining the decision to give the Sprinter the top prize ahead of other similar vans from other auto manufacturers, a spokesperson for VansA2Z said:
"One reason why we are so impressed with this versatile Sprinter variant is the presence of an automatic electronic traction system instead of mechanical differential locks."

item.title: Mercedes highlights advantages of genuine brake kits for Actros and Atego
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes-Benz has said that users of its heavy commercial vehicles, such as the Mercedes Actros, Atego and Axor, should be using genuine brake kits over competing products.
The auto manufacturer has recently extended its range of commercial vehicle brake kits, making them available not only for the Atego, Axor and Actros but also for Mercedes vans like the Sprinter 901-904 model series and the Vario.
The company has quite rightly pointed out that competing kits, whilst they may be widely available and occasionally cheaper, do not guarantee the same quality and durability as genuine Mercedes parts.
Most fleet managers would agree that it is worthwhile to spend a little more money to source genuine parts for fleet vehicles, as they are be specially designed and calibrated to fit the specific vehicle.
Genuine parts and kits can also be relied upon to be fit for purpose, as well as to go the distance and not need replacing frequently. This can help fleets to avoid or limit downtime, service and maintenance in the long run, thereby saving the fleet money. For these reasons and many more, it is always worth tracking down genuine parts.

item.title: Anticipating the brand new Mercedes Econic
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded: Ever since Mercedes-Benz announced that it will be launching a brand new Econic truck later this year, levels of excitement as well as speculation have been rising. The Mercedes Econic has been a godsend to the waste collection and management industry, as it is practically tailor-made for collection, sweeping and delivery. It is widely used by local authorities, as well as by companies in the private sector. The Econic not only excels in the waste management and collection sectors, however, as it also has other applications. It has previously been involved in everything from fire services and airport tarmac to catering and food and drink deliveries. The brand new Econic Released later in 2013, the new Econic is designed to be cleaner and greener than ever before. The new levels of efficiency will be great news for companies and councils with sustainability targets to meet and carbon foot prints to stamp down. The new model is also expected to be stronger than ever before, as well as easier to use. Like its predecessors, the new Econic will be multi-use, so it can be put to a wide range of different applications.

item.title: If you’re looking for cargo space, look no further than the Sprinter van
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded: One of the most important things that fleet managers look for in commercial vans is space. Everyone wants to find the vehicle with the highest roof, the longest body and the greatest cargo-bearing weight. If space, space and more space is your key criteria in a van, look no further than the latest version of the Mercedes Sprinter van. How much can it actually hold? The capacity of the Sprinter van depends greatly on which model variant you choose. If you go for the largest, longest, strongest variant, you can expect a maximum of: •185 inches of cargo length •78.2 inches of cargo height •547 cubic feet of cargo volume In addition, the most powerful engine you can get with the Sprinter is a highly impressive 3.0L turbodiesel V-6, 188 hp. How does it compare? In many tests and reviews for cargo space, the Mercedes Sprinter comes out on top. It simply offers more space and a greater loading capacity than its rivals in the same category, considering the size of the vehicle. It also has the added benefit of being a real workhorse – strong, reliable and highly versatile.

item.title: It’s all change at the top for Mercedes-Benz dealer S & B Commercials
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: One of Britain’s biggest and most successful commercial vehicle dealers is going for growth under the leadership of a new-look senior management team. S & B Commercials is responsible for sales and support of the award-winning Mercedes-Benz truck and van ranges, as well as Fuso Canter light trucks. [caption id="attachment_1766" align="aligncenter" width="460"] Leading from the front… S & B Commercials’ new Dealer Principal Daniel Holmes is flanked by colleagues, from left, Mark Robinson, Graham Balsom, Colin Davis and Tony Thrower[/caption]   The company operates from impressive, three-storey headquarters in Welham Green, Hatfield, and other main dealerships at Stansted andThurrock, as well as a series of vehicle maintenance units. Its area of responsibility takes in Hertfordshire, Essex, and north and eastLondon. Winner of the coveted Mercedes-Benz Commercial Dealer of the Year trophy for 2010 – and on two previous occasions since it being awarded the German manufacturer’s franchise in 1992 – S & B employs 263 people and boasts a turnover just shy of £100 million. Despite this the dealer has remained true to its family business ethos and in keeping with its policy of developing its own staff all five of those now leading the company team have been promoted from within. New Dealer Principal Daniel Holmes takes over from his father Ron. Daniel joined the business in 2004 and has held various positions including Site Manager at Stansted and, since 2008, Director of Operations. Ron founded S & B Commercials in 1982 and although he has now relinquished day-to-day control of the business stays on as Chairman. Meanwhile, Ron’s long-term right-hand manNick Lambert– one of no fewer than 10 staff members to have chalked-up 30 years or more service – has stood down from his role as Director of Sales in order to focus on special projects. Promoted in his place to the company’s top sales job is Graham Balsom, who joined S & B in 2000. Graham’s previous position of Van Sales Manager has gone to Mark Robinson, a member of the S & B team since 2005. Both are high achievers and have won numerous awards from the manufacturer for their sales performances. Another serial award winner is Tony Thrower, a former Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicle Service Manager of the Year, who steps up from his previous role as Group After Sales Manager to become Director of After Sales. Tony began his Mercedes-Benz career in 1988 as an apprentice truck technician working for another dealer, but moved to S & B in 2009 to run theThurrockworkshop. Completing the round of internal promotions is Colin Davis, a chartered accountant who joined the dealership in 2011 as Financial Controller. Having led the dealer’s eight-strong finance team with distinction, he becomes the company’s new Director of Finance. Says Daniel: “We’ve set ourselves some very ambitious growth targets for the next few years. But with the right management team in place, the industry’s finest product range and some first class facilities, I’m confident that we’re perfectly placed to achieve our goals.” [caption id="attachment_1771" align="aligncenter" width="461"] Winning team… S & B Commercials’ new Dealer Principal Daniel Holmes, right, with colleagues, from left, Mark Robinson, Graham Balsom, Colin Davis and Tony Thrower[/caption]

item.title: Daimler truck makes an appearance in Transformers 4 movie
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Following the release of a sneak peek photo of the new Transformers movie, the fourth in the popular franchise, eagle-eyed auto fans have spotted that the Optimus Prime is actually a redesigned Daimler truck.
Daimler, the company which makes Mercedes trucks and vans, also owns Western Star, which has been revealed to have created the upgraded, custom-built unit especially for the Transformers 4 film. This is according to the website of Transformers director Michael Bay, who also revealed that the new film will be taking the franchise and its story in an exciting new direction.
The re-designed Daimler truck will be used for the character of Autobot leader Optimus Prime, who it has been revealed will continue to be voiced by Peter Cullen. The film itself will be released later in the summer, with a U.S. release scheduled for June 24th, 2013.
For many fans of Daimler vehicles, the use of the truck in the film will demonstrate yet again how versatile the vehicles are. Just like Mercedes vans and trucks, they can be custom-built and tailored to a huge range of different purposes, including, it seems, for transforming, shape-shifting robot aliens!

item.title: Cardiff security company switches whole fleet to Mercedes vans
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The owner of a leading fire and security company operating out of Cardiff has made the decision to replace his whole fleet with Mercedes vans, after attending a marketing event and being hugely impressed with what he saw. The founder of Concept Fire and Security, Mr Smith, got his first glimpse of some of the latest Mercedes van models last year, at a local marketing event. He previously only had a Mercedes Vito van belonging to his wife, but after the event decided to invest in two brand new Mercedes Vito vans. Mr Smith also picked out a vehicle from the brand new Citan range, which represents Mercedes-Benz’ first foray into the small van market. With numerous fuel saving features, including a frugal 90hp diesel engine, the start/stop function and low rolling resistant tyres, the new Mercedes Citan is able to boast a market-leading mpg of up to 65.7 whilst also delivering low CO2 emissions of 112 g/km. Clearly impressed with the specifications, Mr Smith explained how both the Vito and the Citan respectively are able to meet the needs of his business:
“It’s a case of ‘horses for courses’. We use the bigger Vito for installations and the smaller, more fuel-efficient Citan for lighter maintenance and repair work.”

item.title: Customised Mercedes Viano vans blowing luxury limos out of the water
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
A company that has been customising Mercedes vans has come up with a range of super-luxe vehicles that serve as everything from mobile offices to relaxing living rooms and even cinemas, in many cases blowing the humble limousine out of the water. Carisma Auto Design, a firm which specialises in converting luxury vehicle interiors, has been able to use the impressive versatility and space found in most Mercedes vans to create super-luxurious custom-designed vehicles for its VIP clients. One of its showcase vehicles, the Carisma Viano, was formerly a Mercedes van. However, it now boasts plush leather seats, refrigerators, a 42-inch television and a number of other bespoke luxury touches. On the outside, the van is far less flashy than a limousine, offering subtlety and privacy for those wanting to arrive at appointments without causing a fuss. Explaining the idea behind the concept, Carisma Auto’s marketing director Clive Drake said:
"Many of our clients are high-profile heads of states, celebrities or important business people, it is therefore not always possible for them to travel around in a conspicuous luxury limousine, however they still want the luxury and comfort that is provided by such a vehicle, this is where the Viano from Carisma comes in.”

item.title: Warrington fleet now boasts Actros trucks and Citan vans
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
A Warrington-based fleet operator is now the proud owner of eight new Mercedes Actros trucks and two Mercedes Citan vans, choosing the vehicles after being impressed with the fuel-efficiency specifications offered by Mercedes-Benz. Mark Thompson Transport has added eight New Actros 2545 tractor units to its 46-strong fleet, along with two of Mercedes new small van, the Citan. The Actros trucks are equipped with GigaSpace cabs, which are the roomiest and the most comfortable available. They are also powered by 450hp, straight-six engines. The Citan, meanwhile, is already delivering market-leading mpg figures, as well as CO2 emissions as low as 112g/km. Commenting on the purchase and explaining the benefits of the New Actros units compared to their predecessors, the managing director of the company, Mark Thompson, said:
"Our fleet includes some units from the previous Actros range, which are solid performers in terms of fuel returns," says Managing Director Mark Thompson. "But the New Actros are returning a seven per cent mpg improvement on our trunking runs - that kind of margin would make a big difference to our bottom line if replicated across the entire fleet."

item.title: Security tips for fleet managers pt.1
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
As a fleet manager, the security of your vehicles and their loads, and the safety of your drivers, should be of the utmost importance. It doesn’t necessarily matter to thieves whether your fleet runs cars, vans or even state-of-the-art Mercedes trucks – they will still seize their opportunities where they can.
To keep your fleet safe, follow these common-sense security tips (continued in part 2 of this guide):
•Train your drivers on what to do if their vehicle is hijacked or they are threatened by someone. Many drivers will go far to protect their vehicle and its cargo, but they shouldn’t be risking their lives. Send drivers on training on topics like staying calm, making mental notes about the crime and its perpetrators and reporting these details to the police.
•Make it company policy for drivers to be discreet about what cargo they are carrying. If it’s something valuable, you don’t want this fact broadcast to the world. You need a company-wide policy on keeping cargo details confidential.
•Invest in the latest security features, including steering locks and alarms. You should also have safes and lock boxes for drivers’ valuable.

item.title: Security tips for fleet managers pt.2
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
After keeping fuel and running costs down, security is one of the biggest issues for fleet managers. However, keeping drivers, vehicles and cargo safe often comes down to following common sense security tips. In part 1 of this guide, we looked at a few of these tips. Now let’s move on to a few more:
•Upgrade GPS systems in vehicles so that if a vehicle is stolen or it goes missing, it can be recovered very quickly
•Ensure your drivers keep their valuables out of sight. It only takes a second for someone to open the vehicle’s door and steal something when the driver briefly leaves the vehicle unattended
•Consider fitting fleet vehicles with security cameras, just in case an incident should happen
•Train drivers on safety and security procedures, including keeping windows rolled up, doors locked and keys away from the vehicle if leaving it unattended.
•Choose vehicles fitted with safety or shatter-proof glass, or those made of ultra-high quality materials, such as Mercedes trucks and vans.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz UK has a record-breaking May for sales figures
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
According to the latest figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), Mercedes-Benz UK had a record-breaking month in May. The SMMT figures show that the company recorded a 16.5 per cent rise in new registrations for Mercedes cars, which is a record figure for the UK arm of Mercedes-Benz. In total, 8,326 new cars were registered in May, making the total for the year to date a whopping 44,615. Also performing exceptionally well was the Commercial Vehicles arm of Mercedes-Benz UK, as registrations in this area were also strong last month. The Mercedes Sprinter van, in particular, managed to achieve a 24.1 per cent rise in registrations last month. In total, Mercedes Sprinter vans sold 1,261 in May and for the year, sales for the Sprinter are up 9.3 per cent. The panel van variant of the Sprinter seems to be the most popular, as it has posted a 15.2 per cent gain for the year so far. Commenting on the company’s continuing success, the President and CEO of Mercedes-Benz UK, Marcus Breitschwerdt, said:
“A strong May and a record-breaking first five months, signs of growth in our Commercial Vehicles operations and another great performance by the AMG brand have put us in a strong position as we enter the summer.”

item.title: Fruit and veg wholesaler switches whole fleet to Mercedes Sprinter vans
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
IA Harris, a highly successful fruit and vegetable wholesaler, has made a decision to convert its entire fleet to Mercedes Sprinter vans by the end of the year. The reason for this drastic change? According to managing director Richard Harris, the “outstanding reliability” of the Sprinter, especially compared to other vehicles in its category. The company has bought new and used Mercedes vans before, having experienced problems with breakdowns and reliability with vehicles from other manufacturers. However, IA Harris is now embarking on a complete fleet change, replacing all of its existing vehicles with 3.5 tonne Mercedes Sprinter vans before the end of 2013. Explaining what the Sprinters will be used for and why it makes sense for the company to buy used Mercedes Vans rather than brand new vehicles, Mr Harris said:
“It’s a tough job. We work our vans very hard and in a typical day each could make as many as 30 drops; so that’s 60 door openings and sometimes more.” “Buying pre-owned, low-mileage Sprinters makes great financial sense for us. We make a decent saving on the new purchase price and the vehicles are outstandingly reliable, as well as being popular with our drivers and loaded with safety features.”

item.title: Sprinter vans converted to luxury mobile homes
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Anyone who has ever driven a Mercedes Sprinter van will know just how versatile the vehicle is, but one entrepreneur in Willoughby, a city in the U.S. state of Ohio, has managed to unlock yet another side of the Sprinter’s potential.
Mike Neundorfer, the former CEO of an air pollution control company, has now decided to start converting Sprinter vans into luxury mobile homes. The Sprinter, often used for delivery and distribution but also for more unusual purposes such as mobile libraries and ambulances, seems to be the perfect vehicle for Advanced RV, Mr Neundorfer’s new company.
The Sprinters are bought in very basic models and are then transformed into luxury holiday spaces, using the latest technology and very high quality materials. It takes 12 weeks, but at the end of the process the vans have solar charging technology, centralised control panels for all electronics and smart phone apps to control temperature. They are also plush and luxurious, featuring granite countertops, high tech-entertainment systems and impressive amenities, including a seven cubic foot fridge and freezer unit.
Advanced RV has made and sold seven of these luxurious mobile homes so far, and as customers have a say in the design, Mr Neundorfer is expecting them to be really popular.
 
For more information on the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter visit www.sbcommercials.co.uk or phone our Van Sales Executives on 01707 261111

item.title: Apple iOS 7 and Mercedes vehicles – how will it work?
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The innovative technology company Apple has announced the launch of its brand new iOS 7 operating system, causing a huge amount of excitement among smartphone and tablet users. However, there is just as much of a buzz within the auto industry, as Apple has also revealed ‘Apple iOS in the Car’, an optimised version of the software which vehicles users can take advantage of.
According to Forbes, ‘iOS in the Car’ will soon be available in new vehicles made by many of the big auto manufacturers. Fans of Mercedes vans, trucks and cars will be delighted to know that the software will be launched in many of the company’s vehicles in 2014. But how will it work?
Apple has revealed that ‘iOS in the Car’ will give drivers turn-by-turn directions with its Maps app. This, along with estimated time of arrival details and traffic updates, will be great news for fleet managers and drivers, making route planning much easier and much more integrated with the vehicle.
Other features, which may benefit car users more than users of Mercedes trucks and vans, include the system's Siri, a virtual assistant, playing voicemails, returning missed calls and reading and replying to texts.

item.title: New Mercedes-Benz Citan, Vito & Axor for GBN Services
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
GBN Services’ Mercedes-Benz-dominated fleet of more than 100 trucks includes a number of six-wheeled tractor units and 8x4 tippers, but the latest addition to the line-up is the smallest commercial vehicle yet to wear a three-pointed star.   The Citan 109 CDI Long was supplied, along with a Vito 113 CDI Compact, by  S & B Commercials in Welham Green. Both are now operating as service vans in and around London, with the Citan’s compact size and fuel efficiency making it particularly well suited to work on the capital’s busy streets.  

Founded in 1986 as a bulk haulage operator, GBN Services is now in the business of skip hire and waste management – it recycles around 94 per cent of the rubbish it collects, with timber a speciality. The company has headquarters at Leyton, and other depots in Uxbridge, New Southgate, Basildon,Harlow(where it has two sites) and Southend. Its eight service vans carry welding and other equipment, and flit between these depots, as well as field locations, maintaining wood processing plant and waste recycling machinery.   Managing Director Garry Hobson says: “Mercedes-Benz has been our preferred truck brand for many years now. It’s a tough job and experience has proved them to be more robust than any competitors’ chassis, so the only non-Mercedes trucks on the fleet are those we have inherited through acquisitions of other operators. “We look for the same attributes of reliability and durability in our service vans, which are permanently loaded and work seven days a week between depots as far as 60 miles apart.”   GBN’s latest 2.8-tonne Mercedes-Benz Vito has joined a couple of other examples from the same product line. “But for most service assignments the Vito is just too big, so we’ve been sourcing the majority of our vans from other manufacturers,” continues Mr Hobson. “Not any more, though. The Citan is the van we’ve been waiting for from Mercedes-Benz. It’s the ideal size and highly cost-effective to run, while also offering the build quality, safety features and after sales back-up we’ve come to expect from the marque. Its introduction means that from now on, all of our service vans will be by Mercedes-Benz.”  
Like GBN Services’ other vehicles the Citan will be serviced under contract by S & B Commercials, which has also just delivered the operator’s latest 18-tonne Mercedes-Benz Axor skip-loader. “S & B do all our maintenance and provide an excellent service,” adds Mr Hobson.

 

Launched in January, the Citan marks the entry of Mercedes-Benz into the small van market and leads the way in terms of fuel efficiency, achieving up to 65.7 mpg and producing CO2 emissions as low as 112 g/km.   GBN Services’ 109 CDI is powered by a 90 hp diesel engine – the Citan is also offered with 75 hp and 110 hp diesels, or a 114 hp petrol unit – and is the subject of a highly flexible Agility funding package from Mercedes-Benz Financial Services. This offers all the benefits of conventional hire purchase with a Guaranteed Future Value (GFV) – including low monthly repayments – but gives operators extra options at the end of the term. Key to the Agility concept is the agreement of a GFV for the vehicle. At the end of the agreement the customer can choose whether to pay off the final lump sum and keep the vehicle, use the vehicle as a part exchange for a brand new one, or return it free of any further obligations, apart from an excess mileage charge if the initially agreed limit has been exceeded, and damage charges over and above fair wear and tear.  

For more information on the Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicle range visit www.sbcommercials.co.uk or contact our Sales Executives on 01707 261111

item.title: Vito wins first place in Van of the Year 2013 competition
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Just after the Mercedes Sprinter and Viano vans took home awards from the Motoring Matters Awards, as well as the Van Fleet Awards, another of the company’s best-selling brands has managed to scoop another prestigious prize.
The Mercedes Vito van took first place in the ‘vans up to 3 tonnes’ category at the 2013 Courier, Express and Parcel Services Van of the Year competition.
Hosted by the ETM-Verlag publishing company, which is based in Stuttgart, the awards are given out by a specialist jury who evaluate each candidate based on criteria such as design, comfort, handling, economy and functionality. The judges also use a range of test results to make their decision, including the data from tests carried out in Warnemunde where each vehicle was put through its paces over 2,500km and 800 different runs.
In addition to the 113 CDI variant of the Mercedes Vito van triumphing in the ‘up to 3 tonnes category’, another Mercedes-Benz vehicle to win big at the awards was the 316 BlueTEC variant of the new Mercedes Sprinter. The Sprinter affirmed its class-leading status by topping the ‘vans up to 3.5 tonnes’ category.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz in Brazil hits 2m milestone for commercial trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The Brazilian arm of Mercedes-Benz, called Mercedes-Benz do Brasil, has recently reported that it has reached a milestone in its commercial vehicle sales. Over the last 57 years, the company has made two million Mercedes trucks, vans and chassis in local manufacturing plants.
In order to reach this impressive milestone, made up of 1.4 million Mercedes trucks and 600,000 other commercial vehicles, Mercedes-Benz do Brasil has had to drum up considerable investment. Around €540 million was invested in the company between 2010 and 2013, allowing it to prepare itself for considerable growth in the years to come. The money was used to increase production capacity and develop fresh products with new engine assembly lines and new technology in manufacturing facilities in Brazil. .
Mercedes-Benz do Brasil is very important to the company, which is owned by Daimler, as a whole. With the latest sales figures showing that 15,820 Daimler trucks were sold in Brazil in the first five months of 2013 so far, a figure that is more than 50 per cent up on the same period last year, it looks like the company is well-positioned for long-term success.

item.title: Improved mpg figures lure haulage firm back to Mercedes trucks after 20 years
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
After 20 years running fleet vehicles from another manufacturer, leading transport firm Mulgrew Haulage has finally decided to make the switch to Mercedes-Benz. Paul Mulgrew, the director of the Northern Ireland based company, has bought 10 new Mercedes Actros trucks for his company. The vehicles are 2545 New Actros models with GigaSpace cabs and 450 hp straight-six engines. Mr Mulgrew made the decision to introduce Mercedes trucks to his fleet after doing some research and realising that the vehicles, and the New Actros in particular, offer much better fuel economy figures than similar vehicles from other manufacturers. In fact, the mpg figures of a demonstration model of a New Actros, which Mulgrew Haulage tested out before placing an order for the new vehicles, were much higher than the fleet average. Commenting on his new purchase, Mr Mulgrew said:
“They’ve only been on the road a month so it’s a little too early to get a benchmark fuel figure but with the evidence of the long-term demo, and what we’ve seen so far, the early signs are very promising,” “Our New Actros tractors are already a little way ahead of the fleet average and we expect them to improve still further as they bed in. They also look fantastic in our colours and are a great advertisement for the company out on the road.”

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter and Viano vans triumph at Motoring Matters awards
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Two of the most popular Mercedes vans in the Mercedes-Benz family, the Sprinter and the Viano, have been honoured with awards from the Motoring Matters Magazine Group Awards 2013. The editorial staff at the Australian publication Delivery Magazine were the judges for the awards, deciding which vehicles have the safety features, exceptional performance and overall quality to be named ‘Van of the Year’ in each category. The expert panel decided on the Mercedes Sprinter van as its ‘Delivery Magazine Van of the Year 2013’. Referring to its brand new set of safety features, including Crosswind Assist, Blind Spot Assist and Collision Prevention Assist, Editor-in-Chief Chris Mullet described the Sprinter as:
“…without doubt the safest van ever to be presented on the Australian market.”
Also receiving a prestigious award was the Mercedes Viano van, which scooped the ‘Best People Mover 2013’ prize. The Viano, called the Mercedes Valente in the Australian market, has won this particular award three years in a row. Thrilled with the latest accolades for Mercedes vans, engineering chief for the company Dr. Sascha Paasche said that the win for the Sprinter in particular:
“…affirms once again the results of our development work in the field of safety.”

item.title: New Mercedes Citan van joins Wrings Transport fleet
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Wrings Transport, the largest privately owned haulage company in the Avonmouth area, has just taken delivery of a brand new Mercedes Citan van, which is the automaker’s smallest ever commercial vehicle. The new Citan, a long-bodied 109 CDI, has a 90hp diesel engine, although it can also be bought in 75hp and 110hp diesel engine variants. There is also a 114hp petrol variant available. The vehicle will be integrated into the existing Wrings Transport fleet, joining other Mercedes vehicles such as three Mercedes Actros trucks and two Mercedes Sprinter vans. Commenting on its new Citan, which is already a market-leader in terms of its fuel efficiency, the company’s managing director Stuart Wring described its performance in a recent trial period. He said:
"We put 4,000 miles on that vehicle in just two weeks, as it went up and down to Glasgow four times," "It proved very economical in terms of fuel consumption, while the feedback from our drivers was also extremely positive; in fact, I drove the Citan myself, just to get a feel for it, and was very impressed." "Mercedes-Benz vans have always been very reliable too. Our Sprinter panel van is now six years old and has clocked-up 300,000 miles, but it's still as good as the day we bought it."

item.title: Key advantages of the new Mercedes Canter Eco Hybrid pt.1
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: When it comes to creating eco-friendly, high performance vehicles with excellent mpg figures and low carbon emissions, Mercedes seems to have it pegged. One of its newest fuel efficient innovations, the Mercedes Canter Eco Hybrid, is already making waves among fleet managers and industry experts. There are a number of good reasons for this, including these 7 key advantages (continued in part 2): 1.DUONIC dual-clutch transmission system. This is Mercedes’ pioneering and highly advanced transmission system, offering the incredible efficiency of a manual system with the handy convenience of an automatic. 2.Hybrid drive technology. This technology works in a very clever way, saving you fuel as you drive and recovering energy in order to top up the battery when you slow down. The battery and the engine work beautifully together, with the former supporting the latter when you start driving again. 3.Ergonomically designed cab. Every aspect of the Canter Eco Hybrid’s cab, like many other Mercedes trucks and vans, is designed with the comfort and needs of the driver (and passengers) in mind. See part 2 of this guide for more of the Mercedes Canter Eco Hybrid’s key advantages.

item.title: Key advantages of the new Mercedes Canter Eco Hybrid pt.2
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: As well as being one of the greenest and cleanest of Mercedes trucks range, the new Canter Eco Hybrid is fast becoming one of its most popular. In part 1 of this guide, we looked at 3 of its main advantages, including: 1.DUONIC dual-clutch transmission system 2.Hybrid drive technology 3.Ergonomically designed cab Now let’s move on to look at a few more: 4.Start/Stop function. This handy function is a fleet managers’ dream, as it saves a huge amount of fuel and lowers emissions by switching the engine off when the vehicle is idling. 5.Reducing fuel consumption by up to 23 per cent. Mercedes claims that compared to a conventional Canter diesel model, the new Eco Hybrid is able to reduce fuel consumption by as much as 23 per cent. 6.High payload. Thanks to its weight-optimised, corrosion-protected frame, the Canter Eco Hybrid is able to support a payload weight that is just shy of 5 tonnes. This impressive weight-carrying capacity may surprise some, especially considering the compactness of the vehicle itself. 7.Good range of body variants. Like all other Mercedes trucks, the Canter Eco Hybrid is available in a huge range of customisable options, including different body variants.

item.title: Parcelforce gets maximum value for money from Mercedes Sprinter fleet
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The UK and international parcel delivery and courier service Parcelforce Worldwide has revealed that its fleet of Mercedes Sprinter vans covered a total of nearly 140,000 miles on 21st June. This was the longest day of the year, with nearly 17 hours of daylight recorded, and Parcelforce vans managed to make the most of every minute.
The company has revealed that on average, its Mercedes vans covered around 11,625 miles every hour on the longest day of the year, with a combined total for the whole day of 139,500. Parcelforce’s fleet managers have to work incredibly hard to minimise downtime for the fleet, which operates out of 53 depots across the UK, but of course it helps to have a van as reliable as the Mercedes Sprinter.
Despite being put to such hard, intense use, the Parcelforce fleet of Sprinters and other Mercedes vans has never failed. In fact, the Sprinter has been specially designed to thrive in these kinds of conditions, where hundreds of miles and long days are all part of an average week. With the continued assistance of 24 hour servicing, the company’s fleet will continue to perform exceptionally.

item.title: Mercedes Actros used to deliver RNLI lookouts
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes Actros is already known as a versatile vehicle suitable for a wide range of different applications, but it has now been put to a brand new use.
The Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) has put the Actros truck to good use, mounting it with a crane and sending it to deliver self-contained lifeguard lookout units to coastal locations around the UK and Northern Ireland. Hundreds of locations along the coast have now received these units, which have arrived just in time for the summer season.
The Mercedes truck being used for the job is an Actros 6x2 tractor unit, which has a semi-trailer and a Hiab XS477 E-6 HiDuo crane mounted upon it. Overall, the RNLI has chosen a very efficient system for delivering units, which will then be quickly and conveniently picked up again and returned to regional storage at season’s end.
This isn’t the first Mercedes truck to be used by the RNLI in this way. The organisation has also used a Mercedes Axor truck, which is smaller than the Actros and a number of other Mercedes trucks, mounting it with another Hiab crane for vital work on behalf of the RNLI.

item.title: Four new Sprinters added to Bradbury Group fleet
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The Bradbury Group, known for manufacturing steel doors, cages, security grilles and safes, has added four brand new Mercedes Sprinter vans to its fleet. The company has customers including the Northern Power Grid, McDonalds, Portakabin, Cable and Wireless and the London Olympics, needs its vans in order to carry tools and equipment to sites all over the UK. Darren Bamford, who is Bradbury Group’s production director, explained what the company was looking for in its new fleet vehicles and why the Sprinter was the ideal choice. He said:
“Our distribution vans will cover some 80,000 miles a year so reliability was at the top of our list of our priorities. We’ve rented Mercedes-Benz vehicles in the past and we know that whereas other manufacturers’ vans start falling to pieces at about 180,000 miles, the Sprinter just keeps on going. “It’s also well equipped, popular with our staff, and widely recognised as the safest van on the road. That’s crucial because as a business we take our duty of care commitments to employees and other road users very seriously indeed.”
The Bradbury Group’s four medium-length Sprinter 313 CDIs will now be assigned to its engineers, and they will be joining the five long-bodied Mercedes Sprinter vans the company bought last year.

item.title: Mercedes Vito is the perfect vehicle for Abu Dhabi’s special needs taxi service
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
After identifying the need for a specially adapted taxi service for people with special needs, the Abu Dhabi transport department has rolled out a fleet of Mercedes Vito vans to serve the city. The project was announced by The Centre for Regulations of Transport by Hire Cars of the Department of Transport (DoT), which decided that a new special needs cab service was needed for Abu Dhabi. Each Mercedes Vito van, chosen due to its versatility and adaptability, has been retro-fitted with bespoke, state-of-the art technologies. The vans also have hydraulic systems to ensure easy and convenient access for people with limited mobility. The aim of the scheme is to provide disabled travellers with convenience and security – which are the basic things that every person wants in a taxi service and which everyone should be entitled to. Commenting on the new fleet of Vito taxis and explaining the benefits of the scheme, the Assistant General Manager for Corporate Service at the centre, Jameela Al Hameli, said:
“Such benefits include connecting vehicles with the ordering and distribution system to ensure efficient operation and users’ hassle-free accessibility to the service as well as the adherence of taxi companies to all standards and regulations set by the centre as they are in line with international standard,”

item.title: Rise in registrations for commercial vehicle market
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
According to the latest figures released by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), the commercial vehicle market has much to be excited about. In June, truck registrations, including those of Mercedes trucks such as the New Actros, rose by a fifth. A total of 3,463 trucks over six tonnes were registered in the UK last month, a considerable rise compared to the 2,893 registrations in the same truck category that were recorded at the same time last year. This is excellent news for the vans and trucks industry, especially considering the fact that the market was still down around 7.5 per cent for the first six months of the year, compared to the same period in 2012. Offering an insight into what the latest figures mean, the commercial vehicle manager for the SMMT, Nigel Base, said that a resurgence in sales and registrations in the later months of 2013 could well be on the cards. He said:
“For trucks, growth in June could be the first sign of a Q3/Q4 recovery as buyers pick from late Euro 5 or new Euro 6 models ahead of new Euro-standard legislation hitting from 2014,"

item.title: Renovated Mercedes van given to food charity
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Many used Mercedes vans are driving around roads in the UK today, but hardly any have gone on the same journey as a van in South Gloucestershire which was renovated by schoolchildren and donated to a local charity.
The van, a Mercedes Vito van, was originally donated by Avon and Somerset Constabulary. It was then renovated by nine youngsters from four secondary schools across the county who were taking part in a community vehicle course run by the Wheels Project. The students attended the course, which is part of the Work2Learn schools programme, every Friday for three whole terms.
Eventually, the hard-working teens attained qualifications in motor vehicle studies, and used their new-found skills to work on the Vito van. They managed to bring it up to MOT standard, and then decided to donate it to a local charity so that the van could be put to good use in the community.
The charity chosen was the East Bristol Foodbank, which operates out of the Community Café in Easton. The Foodbank was in need of reliable transport, as it needed to transport food from a warehouse to the café each week, as well as to drop enough food for 400 people off at a local drop-in centre.

item.title: Tyre care tips for greater fuel and cost efficiency
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Fuel efficiency is one of the most pressing things on any fleet manager’s mind. However, optimising the fuel efficiency of your fleet does not simply mean finding the cheapest fuel or choosing the latest and most fuel efficient Mercedes trucks, although these things do help. You also need to think about maintenance and servicing, with your fleet’s tyres being an area of particular concern.
The lifespan of tyres can be affected and shortened by a whole range of different factors, from weather and road surface conditions to tyre pressure, the vehicle’s load and even the driver’s behaviour on the road.
There are many things fleet managers can do to ensure that the tyres their fleet vehicles are fitted with last as long as possible, as well as ensuring maximum fuel efficiency. Follow these tips:
•Make sure tyres are checked every 4,000 to 6,000 miles of driving •Keep a close eye on tyre tread depth, ensuring all tyres are replaced when they reach 3mm •Maintain the right tyre pressure to ensure safety, fuel efficiency, proper vehicle handling and a long life for the tyre •Choose fuel efficient tyres for your vehicles, using the new labelling system (tyres labelled ‘A’ are the most fuel efficient, ‘G’ the least).

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter van scoops its 8th ‘Fleet Van of the Year’ prize
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Ever since the first Mercedes Sprinter was launched onto the UK market, it has been showered with prestigious awards and won over hundreds of thousands of fans. It is consistently talked about as the UK’s most popular and best-selling commercial van. However, the Sprinter van has now managed to top its previous achievements after being named the ‘Fleet Van of the Year’ at the annual Motor Transport Awards for the eighth year. It has won this very same award in the very same category in 2003, 2004, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2012, showing just how much UK businesses and van enthusiasts really do love the Sprinter. Commenting on the win, the managing director of commercial vehicles at Mercedes-Benz UK, Michael Kamper, said:
“This is another outstanding achievement for the versatile and trustworthy Sprinter,” “Being awarded Motor Transport’s Fleet Van of the Year for the eighth time is an honour which allows us the knowledge of how the vehicle is thought of and received both by our customers and the judging panel.”
As well as its reliability and versatility, the new breed of Sprinter vans is fast becoming known for market-leading safety systems. Sprinters now have Adaptive ESP (Electronic Stability Programme), which works alongside Brake Assist, acceleration skid control, electronic brake force distribution and a range of other features to ensure ultimate safety on the road.

item.title: Hire firm loves the flexibility of its first ever Fuso Canter trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
A leading hire firm specialising in plant, accommodation and toilet hire has taken delivery of its first ever Fuso Canter trucks, and its already thrilled with how flexible the vehicles are. The five new Fuso Canter 3C13s are now in the service of Nixon Hire, a company operating in the north of England. The 3.5 tonne vehicles have been specified with DUONIC gearboxes, which enables the twin-plate, dual clutch automatic transmission to shift smoothly and economically between gears with minimal frictional loss. The vehicles will primarily be used to deliver portable toilet units to sports events and music festivals, as well as construction and building sites. According to Nixon Hire’s Transport Manager Graham Wood, the Mercedes trucks are already proving themselves more than up for the job. He said:
"We can now carry 18 toilets at a time but the Canter remains suitable for multi-drop runs, which sometimes require access to tight locations. It's a multi-purpose vehicle and suits both needs extremely well." "We're certainly impressed by what we've seen so far, while the response from our drivers has also been very positive - the DUONIC transmission makes these vehicles very easy to drive.”

item.title: Safety charity publishes young driver risk reports for fleet managers
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Brake, the road safety charity, has published a pair of new reports designed to help fleet managers to manage the risks of young drivers at work. According to Brake, the most common cause of death for 15 to 24 year olds throughout the world is traffic fatalities. This, along with the fact that at-work drivers of any age are around 26 per cent more likely to experience a road traffic accident than other drivers, means that this high-risk age group really needs to be managed. Even if fleet managers have the safest vehicles, such as Mercedes vans and trucks with their market-leading safety features, an accident involving a young driver could still happen. The first report is a survey of fleet managers highlighting worrying statistics such as that 23 per cent of fleet managers couldn’t say what proportion of their vehicle collisions involve a young driver, leaving them unable to assess and mitigate risk. The second report is best practice guidance for fleet managers, helping them to minimise risks and maximise safety of the fleet as a whole. There are apparently two more reports to come from Brake on this subject, as part of a huge campaign by the charity. Brake’s professional engagement manager Roz Cumming said:
"Fleet managers must be proactive in managing the risks associated with young drivers. This includes keeping an up-to-date record of drivers' ages, as well as detailed records of drivers' involvement in crashes.”

item.title: New Mercedes Actros trucks help Southampton hauliers slash fuel costs
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The Southampton-based container transport specialist IPL Haulage has taken delivery of its first ever Mercedes trucks, in the hope that the new vehicles can help the fleet make drastic cuts to its fuel costs. A pair of brand New Actros 2545 tractors with BigSpace cabs have now been delivered to IPL’s base in Totton, and another pair of identical vehicles will be delivered in January 2014. The operator made the decision to switch from its established supplier to Mercedes after learning about the impressive mpg figures the New Actros has been delivering. Commenting on a trial that was carried out with two demonstrator Actros models, managing director Ian Percival said:
“I allocated one to a very good driver, and the other to a guy who's less experienced," "It's difficult to make accurate comparisons, because our work is so varied. But the good driver achieved 9.5 mpg, which is very encouraging given that our fleet average is 8.75 mpg. The second driver didn't do quite as well but still returned 9.1 mpg, an improvement of almost 0.4 mpg."
Mr Percival also commented on the smart appearance of the Mercedes trucks, saying that the Actros is “undoubtedly the best looking truck on the road right now.”

item.title: The impressive safety features of the brand new Sprinter van
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The new Mercedes Sprinter van has lots going for it, from smart design to impressive fuel efficiency. However, one of the most talked-about aspects of the 2013 model is safety, as the new Sprinter has a host of pioneering safety features.
Safety in the new Mercedes Sprinter van is assured by these rather impressive safety features and systems:
•Adaptive ESP (Electronic Stability Program). This system, for the very first time, takes account of the vehicle load using very sensitive sensors to perform stabilising interventions throughout the course of a trip. •Trailer Stability Assist. An extension of the Adaptive ESP, this function is designed to counteract swaying and other trailer movements so that the driver can stabilise the vehicle. •Acceleration and braking safety systems, including Brake Assist (BAS), anti-lock brake system (ABS), acceleration skid control (ASR) and electronic brake force distribution (EBD). •Front airbag for the driver as standard and optional front airbag for the passenger. You can also get window bags and thorax bags for both driver and passenger •Rain sensor with Headlamp Assist as an optional feature •Three-point seat belts on all seats, with a seat belt warning for the driver’s seat as standard.

item.title: First details of 2014 Mercedes Viano revealed
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Although Mercedes-Benz itself has not made any announcements regarding the upcoming 2014 Mercedes Viano van, spy photographers at worldcarfans.com have managed to get themselves a sneak peek of the new model.
The vehicle pictured on the website is heavily camouflaged, but a few exciting design elements are still noticeable. It appears that the 2014 Viano van will have a very modern design in line with the brand’s latest styling philosophy, with a gently curving front bumper, large headlights and a prominent grille. The new Viano also has a taller hood and a beltline that sweeps upwards, presumably to adhere to new stricter laws on pedestrian safety.
Not a lot is known about the engine options with the 2014 Viano, but industry insiders are predicting that it will be available with a variety of four and six cylinder units.
Whilst it may not be as sought-after or as showered with prestigious awards as the Sprinter, the Mercedes Viano van is still very much in demand among commercial customers. A hugely versatile and flexible multi-purpose vehicle, the design of the Viano was originally based on that of the successful Mercedes Vito van, which continues to sell well in the UK and throughout the world.

item.title: More Sprinter vans added to the Fairways Group fleet
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The Fairways Group, a family-owned company based in Glasgow, has added two brand new Mercedes Sprinter vans and one new Mercedes Citan van to its existing fleet. The two Sprinter 313 CDI vans and Citan 108 CDI will be put to work in the company’s Sportsgrounds division, which maintains bowling greens and lawns for many high profile sporting events. The new vans are already being used to get the laws ready at the Kelvingrove Bowling Centre, which is the host location for the Commonwealth Games Gold Medals event in summer 2014. Commenting on the new members of the Fairways Group, contracts director Dave Gibson said:
“Our previous Sprinters have served us extremely well so we had no hesitation in choosing more Mercedes-Benz vehicles. “We were keen to maintain a consistent corporate image, by having the same smart, professional-looking vans across our divisions. But we also wanted vehicles which would be reliable and safe for our operatives, as well as offering low operating costs and coming with the safety net of high quality support from a local dealer. The Sprinter ticks all of those boxes.”
The 129hp engines in the new Sprinters are known to be very fuel efficient and around 15 per cent more economical than the engines used in previous Sprinter models.

item.title: New Citan van’s endurance tested with round UK trip
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The brand new Mercedes Citan van is causing a lot of excitement amongst industry insiders and commercial customers, not only because it is so compact and reliable but also because Mercedes is boasting of its impressive endurance by billing it as being “born to run”. But just how much staying power does the new Citan van have? To prove the toughness of the new Citan, the vehicle was subjected to a fairly epic challenge. A new Citan was sent on a gruelling round trip of the UK, covering nearly 4,000 miles in just nine days and visiting all 98 Mercedes-Benz dealers from Aberdeen to Truro. In total, the Citan required just six full tanks of diesel fuel to make the journey, proving its fuel efficiency as well as its endurance. Needless to say, the Citan made it to the end of its journey without upset and in good time, which should be good news for commercial customers considering adding the compact super-van to their fleets. Commenting on the challenge, Mercedes-Benz Vans’ sales and marketing director Steve Bridge said:
“This epic trip neatly proves that no matter how hard our vans are driven and the hours put in, we’re on-hand to provide support to our customers – both the product and our network of dealers are capable of meeting and exceeding their justifiably high expectations and keeping Mercedes-Benz vans running, and running.”

item.title: 10th Mercedes-Benz Van Experience attracts record attendees
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
The 2013 Mercedes-Benz Van Experience, a marketing event that is now in its 10th year, managed to attract record attendance figures when it was held in Warwickshire this June. Over two consecutive weeks, more than 1,800 Mercedes van fans and potential customers turned up to the Prodrive circuit in Warwickshire to take a sneak peek at some of the brand’s newest van models. As well as being able to see models such as the new Mercedes Citan, Sprinter and Vito up-close, customers could even give the vehicles a test drive. Other events and activities held during the 10th annual Mercedes-Benz Van Experience included the Mercedes Sprinter 4x4 challenge, as well as the mpg and the skid pan challenge. The Mercedes Citan, in particular, performed exceptionally well in the mpg challenge, achieving 99 mpg on a number of occasions over the two mile marathon circuit. Commenting on the runaway success of the event, commercial customer Mark Lovett told FleetNews:
"This is the fifth time that I've visited Van Experience and I find it incredibly useful and informative. "Being able to test a wide range of differing models, all within the closed confines of this fantastic venue, enables us to greater understand the vehicles and ultimately build a clearer picture of what we and our van clients are looking for.”
.

item.title: Vito Sport X the surprise winner of TG Magazine’s Speed Week
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
When Top Gear magazine held its annual Performance Car of the Year Showdown, most supercar fans fancied high-end speed machines like the Porsche Cayman or the Lamborghini Aventador Roadster to triumph. Instead, the real star of Top Gear’s Speed Week was a van – the Mercedes Vito Sport X to be specific.
Mercedes Vito vans are known for reliable, versatile and great for transporting both passengers and goods, but we now know just how nippy certain Vito models can be. Top Gear magazine’s testers found that the Vito Sport X, which it was only using as a support vehicle, could manage 0-62 mph in just 9.1 seconds, which is a fantastic result for a van.
The Vito Sport X, with its 3.0 litre V6 turbodiesel engine, often found in Mercedes road cars, also boasts 325lb ft. of torque and 221 of bhp. The magazine also notes that alongside its power and speed, the Sport X variant of the popular Vito van also offers excellent control around corners, as proved by its staying power around the TG racetrack. With a lower suspension than a standard Vito, the Sport X is able to negotiate bends and corners like a dream, especially if fitted with the right tyres and alloys.

item.title: Dixon International adds six New Actros trucks to its fleet
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
One of the leading distribution and logistics companies in Ireland, Dixon International has added six new Mercedes Actros trucks to its fleet. The family-run company, which is based in Swords in North County Dublin, specialises in national and international haulage. Dixon’s managers already ordered two new Actros trucks earlier in the year, and were obviously so impressed that they’ve taken delivery of six more. The new Mercedes trucks being added to the Dixon fleet are New Actros 1845 trucks with top of the line BigSpace cabs, providing optimum comfort and convenience for drivers. The trucks will all be wrapped in the company’s signature navy blue and white livery, joining the rest of the fleet right away. Commenting on the decision to take on so many New Actros trucks, the managing director of Dixon International, Michael Dixon, said:
“The reputation the new Actros has gained in terms of comfort, driving dynamics and most importantly, fuel economy, meant we just had to try them. Prior to placing our order, the demonstrations we did were excellent so we are looking forward to seeing how well these trucks perform under operating conditions.”

item.title: How is your fleet managing road risk?
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
As a fleet manager, you will naturally want to reduce and mitigate risk to fleet vehicles and drivers as much as possible. But are you going the right way about it?
The road safety charity Brake has now published guidance for fleet managers on managing road risk. In the new best practice report, the charity explains how spotting the risks of vehicle collisions and learning how to manage them can be financially beneficial to fleet managers, as well as saving lives and helping the environment.
The expert advice in the report, which was included in a recent web seminar from Brake, also outlines how engaging with fleet insurers can be a good idea for managers.
Brake estimates that at-work crashes in the UK cost around £2.7 billion a year. Even small collisions and bumps can be very expensive, especially if fleets have only just invested in top-of-the range vehicles like the new Mercedes Sprinter 2013 van, for example. In total, the cost of a fleet vehicle insurance claim can actually be up to 15 times higher than the cost of direct repair, which is reason enough on its own for fleet managers to take steps to manage road risks and avoid collisions.

item.title: Mercedes-Benz UK reports best ever first half-year
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
According to the latest figures released by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), Mercedes-Benz UK had a record first half of the year in 2013. The figures show that the UK branch of the auto manufacturer achieved its best ever registration results in the second quarter (Q2) of the year. A total of 25,470 new Mercedes vehicles were registered in Q2, contributing to Mercedes-Benz’s best ever market share for the year to date. The cars which saw increases in registrations for the company included the Mercedes C-Class Coupe and the CLS-Class and the SL-Class. However, Mercedes-Benz Commercial Vehicles also performed exceptionally well, with the Citan van in particular having its best month ever in June with more than 200 new registrations. The Mercedes Actros truck saw an increase in registrations of 62.7 per cent, a huge rise for the vehicle, and the Mercedes Axor and Econic also did well, with registrations increasing by 127.7 per cent and 53.1 per cent. Commenting on the figures, a delighted Marcus Breithschwerdt, the CEO of Mercedes-Benz UK, said:
“Strong individual performances by key models across our passenger car and commercial vehicle operations, such as the Citan van, the new E-Class Saloon and the Actros as well as the continued great gains by AMG gave us a record performance in June and in the second quarter of the year.”

item.title: New Actros wins on mpg in distribution firm’s truck trial
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Following a trial to find the most fuel efficient vehicle to add to its fleet, a leading distribution firm has plumped for the new Mercedes Actros truck. McCulla, an operator based in the Northern Irish city of Lisburn, pitted demonstration units from all the main truck manufacturers against each other to find the cheapest and most efficient to run. The clear winner was the Mercedes Actros truck, as the company’s transport director Brian Beattie explained:
"Readings from the Daimler FleetBoard telematics systems on the new vehicles tell us they are averaging well over 9mpg, and some are consistently returning better than 10mpg.”
Following the trial, McCulla didn’t hesitate on the decision to purchase 10 New Actros trucks. The operator settled on New Actros 2545 units with StreamSpace cabs, which are known to be incredibly aerodynamic and great for improving mpg figures. Mr Beattie also said that once the vehicles have had time to settle in, and the fleet’s drivers have had some specialist training and tips in how best to drive the New Actros, he fully expects the vehicles to achieve a fuel efficiency level of 9.75mpg on an everyday basis.

item.title: Driver challenge day focuses on safety for fleet drivers
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A driver challenge day held by the telematics provider Masternaut and sponsored by Mercedes-Benz is focusing on fleet safety, with many activities planned that will help participants think about how they can be fostering a culture of responsibility and safety within their fleet.
The event, which took place at the Donnington Park Racing Circuit, brought together a select group of key decision-makers within the UK’s fleet and transport industries. Around 50 participants turned up, from companies such as DHL, EDF and Network Rail.
As the key focus of the driver challenge day was safety, most of the activities were based around how to make fleets safer.
Masternaut took the lead with a telematics-based event, in which participants were challenged to make it round a circuit of the track in the safest way they could. Whilst they drove Mercedes Sprinter vans around the track, the on-board telematics systems recorded everything from speeding and harsh braking to idling time, with all the results fed back to the drivers at the end of the circuit.
Other events on the day included parallel parking challenges, interactive discussions on safety best practice and road risk, ABS testing, and of course, the presentation of an award to the ‘driver challenge champion’.

item.title: New Mercedes Sprinter the ideal choice for sauce company
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
When a distribution company specialising in the delivery of sauces and other catering products was in need of a new fleet vehicle, the Mercedes Sprinter van was the ideal choice.
New and used Mercedes Sprinter vans are hugely popular in the UK, partly because of the reliability of the model and partly because of its agility, compact frame and impressive loading capacity. However, the Sprinter’s secret weapon is its versatility, as it can be put to virtually any purpose and still perform exceptionally.
This was the case for Rich Sauces, an Irish company operating out of Ballymount near Dublin, when it was looking for a new distribution van. The versatility and easy customisation of the Sprinter was ideal, as it could be fitted with a refrigeration unit perfect for transporting its award-winning sauces and other catering products to restaurants nationwide.
The ideal vehicle for Rich Sauces was a Mercedes Sprinter 316 long wheel base van, a model which was no doubt covered in the livery of the company. With its impressive loading capacity and ability to go the distance, the new Sprinter should prove a big success for the sauce and catering products specialist.

item.title: Mercedes Sprinter gets a luxurious makeover in California
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes Sprinter vans are primarily used as commercial vehicles, working hard for companies of all sizes in industries such as distribution and delivery. However, one company based in California has seen a different kind of potential in the versatile Sprinter.
Lexani Motorcars takes an ordinary Sprinter van as its base, stripping it down to the bare essentials before giving it a complete luxury makeover. Its new Reale vehicles, marketed at wealthy individuals and high-flying business executives wanting to travel in style and supreme comfort, are fitted with all the luxuries and conveniences a traveller could want.
The Reale can be specified to the client’s demands, but many have a 46-inch 3D TV built in to the partition between the driver and passenger areas, along with a separate bathroom area, drinks fridge, bar and microwave, luxury leather seats and stunning décor. The revamped Sprinters also come with armoured exteriors if necessary.
In short, the Reale has everything the discerning VIP could want from a luxury vehicle. It’s not quite what the designers of Mercedes Sprinter vans had in mind when creating the model, but the Reale just goes to show how versatile the Sprinter can be, as well as how much space it has to offer.

item.title: Brit European runs its first New Actros trucks
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
Brit European, a leader in the world of logistics, has started running its very first Mercedes New Actros trucks, and is so impressed that the company is already planning to order more. The operator, which has its headquarters in Crewe and specialises in distribution, road haulage and logistics solutions, has recently taken delivery of its first fleets of New Actros trucks. The new arrivals are made up of 10 New Actros LSnR Volumer models, which have been specified with super streamlined StreamSpace cabs, low frame-heights and air suspension at the front and rear. These 10 new Mercedes trucks have already been put into action for Brit European, operating in Zeebrugge for the Belgium arm of the company. These trucks and any others added to the operator’s fleet will be used to distribute palletised goods, along with floor coverings and carpets, to destinations throughout Europe. Speaking of the performance of its new fleet so far, the company’s managing director Graham Lackey said:
"First impressions of the New Actros units based in Zeebrugge are entirely positive - it's the best-looking truck on the road right now, driver feedback has been excellent and we're very encouraged by the initial fuel returns which appear to be some six per cent of the existing fleet.”
Brit European is planning to invest a total of £5 million in Mercedes trucks and trailers this year and the next, with a further investment of £3 million planned for 2014.

item.title: Southampton electricians make the switch to extra-long Vito vans
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Refix, an electrical services specialist based in Southampton, has made the decision to switch its whole fleet of vehicles to Mercedes Vito vans, after learning just how clean and economical they are to run. The company, which also handles property maintenance, has bought five Mercedes Vito vans, all with extra-long bodies so that they could be racked out and customised for use by Refix’s electrical engineers. Four of the Vitos are 113 CDI models, with one being a 163hp Vito 116 CDI. All have four cylinder engines mated to ECO-Gear six-speed manual gearboxes. This makes them very economical, with great fuel efficiency, and it also reduces Refix’s carbon footprint. However, the Vito’s great fuel efficiency and green credentials aren’t the only reason Refix, which has been operating since 1988, decided to make its first investments in Mercedes vans now. Managing director Chris Mansfield also loves how safe the Vito is, explaining:
“Our engineers love their new Mercedes-Benz vans and I have to confess that I had not fully appreciated previously how much better is their standard specification compared to our previous vehicles, particularly in relation to safety.” “Our staff cover high mileages in all weathers and at all times of the day and night, so it’s reassuring to know that we’re putting them on the road in the safest van in its class.”

item.title: Surrey florist making great use of the compact Mercedes Citan
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A florist business in Surrey has made the decision to swap its fleet of Mercedes Vito vans with more compact Mercedes Citan vans, and the move is already paying off. Gareth and Amanda Sweet, who run Rays Florist Ltd in Ash, are already reaping the benefits of the Citan, which marks Mercedes-Benz’s first entry into the small van market. The company no longer needs the larger Vito to buy flowers from wholesale markets, as suppliers now deliver directly to them. The business now only needs high performing, fuel efficient vehicles to provide its same-day flower delivery service in the UK, and the Citan fits the bill perfectly. Commenting on his new long-bodied Citan 109 CDI BlueEFFICIENCY van, which has been decked out in the company’s striking pink livery, owner Gareth Sweet said:
“We planned our vehicle requirements around the Citan coming out and I’m glad we did,” “Not only is it the perfect size for our business, but we’re already making valuable savings on our fuel bill too.” “It’s living up to all our expectations. The Citan looks great and is a joy to drive, while also proving highly economical to run.”

item.title: Mercedes Actros trucks make the epic journey from Germany to Russia
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The Mercedes Actros truck is famous for both its stamina and its versatility, and both have been put to the test by the team behind the DTM race car as they made their way from Germany to the very first DTM race in Russia.
A total of six Actros trucks were needed to transport all the equipment needed for the touring car championship’s inaugural race at the Moscow Raceway, which was held at the start of August and won by Mike Rockenfeller. The vehicles embarked on an epic journey, travelling over 2,600 kilometres from the DTM team’s headquarters in Germany to Russia, passing through Poland, Lithuania and Latvia as they went.
Truck driver Charl Lohrman, who was one of the drivers on the journey, implied that he couldn’t have picked a better vehicle than the Mercedes Actros truck for such an arduous transport job. Reliable, safe and hardworking, the Actros was perfect for transporting the team’s valuable cargo of Mercedes AMG cars on such a long journey. With the help of logistics specialists, loading and unloading was no problem for the Actros either, as the team confirmed that it only took around an hour for loading and unloading.

item.title: Fleet management fuel efficiency tips – improving driving behaviour
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Improving fuel efficiency is the number one priority for many fleet managers, and there are many ways to go about it. It all starts with choosing the right vehicles, such as market-leading Mercedes trucks and vans capable of delivering impressive mpg figures as well as low emissions. However, the driving behaviour and style of fleet drivers could also make a huge difference to fuel efficiency. Even the greenest Mercedes vans and trucks will underperform on fuel efficiency if driven improperly. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) is currently estimating that UK drivers could collectively save nearly £7 billion a year in fuel by adapting their driving style, and that’s just individual drivers. By investing in better driver training and developing a greater understanding of how driving behaviour affects fuel consumption, fleets could reap huge benefits. As well as meeting carbon emissions targets, companies could save millions in fuel costs. Peter Davenport, who is a managing director of fleet management specialists Motiva, said:
“In general, if someone is driving a fleet van or car they are likely to be less concerned about, say, harsh acceleration, than if they were in their own car. “That has a really significant impact of fuel consumption – and of course cost to the employer. “It also means that if fleet managers work with drivers to instil good habits, the savings could be even greater.”

item.title: New Citan joins Sprinter and Vito vans in signage company fleet
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
The signage specialist Dragon Signs & Print has added the brand new, super-compact Mercedes Citan van to its fleet, where it will join other vehicles from the Mercedes vans family such as the Sprinter and the Vito. The company, which has its head office in Cardiff, chose the smallest ever van made by Mercedes to handle smaller jobs where the Vito and the Sprinter prove too large. Explaining how the new Citan van can save the business on fuel costs by handling these smaller, everyday jobs, Dragon’s managing director Rhys Harrington said:
“We use the Sprinter for large external signage installations and the two Vito models for most routine projects, “But even they’ve been too big on occasion, which is where the Citan comes in. It’s ideal as a little runaround for smaller jobs, and means that we’re able to restrict our fuel costs to an absolute minimum.”
The company’s new Citan 109 CDI BlueEFFICIENCY may be small, but it can still carry up to five members of the Dragon Signs & Print team thanks to a clever split-folding bench behind the two front seats. The business also chose an extra-long Citan Dualiner model, which offers a practical and spacious load compartment whilst still being a very compact vehicle.

item.title: Reliable Sprinter vans trusted with transporting customer records in London
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
When records management specialist Deepstore needed a fleet of vehicles to safely and reliably transport important client documents around London, there was only one model to turn to – the Mercedes Sprinter. One of the most popular commercial vans in the UK, if not the most popular, the Mercedes Sprinter van has a lot to recommend it. For Deepstore, the space available in the Long-bodied variant of the 313 CDI Sprinter was a great asset, making it ideal for storing all kinds of critical documents and files. The six new Sprinter vans taken on by Deepstore to operate from its two active storage facilities in Bromley-by-Bow in East London and Wallington in Surrey are also very reliable, which is essential if the company is to provide its two-hour and same-day retrieval services. Commenting on the new additions to its fleet, Deepstore’s UK logistics manager Chris Gamble said:
“Our new vans replace a previous batch of Sprinters that were nearly eight years old but had proved exceptionally reliable. They were a great testament to the Mercedes-Benz brand. “It’s crucial that our uniformed drivers should feel safe and confident in their vans so we listened carefully to the feedback we’d had from Bow and Wallington before deciding to go with the Sprinter again.”

item.title: The New Actros - protecting drivers and cargo with 10 key safety systems
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded: The New Actros is a winner with fleet managers and business owners for a number of different reasons – its incredible fuel efficiency, innovative design and unfailing reliability, to name but a few. However, the new Mercedes Actros also scores top marks for safety. When it comes to protecting drivers and cargo whilst out on the roads, the New Actros is unrivalled. It has no less than 10 specially designed safety systems, some of which you will find on no other vehicle – except perhaps other Mercedes trucks and vans.
