Safety in the New Actros The new Mercedes Actros boasts the following safety features, plus many others: 1.Active Brake Assist 2 2.Tyre Pressure Monitor 3.Electronic Brake System, which also has traction control 4.Driver Airbag 5.Lane Assistant – to prevent drifting and to help make changing lanes easier and safer for drivers 6.Auto-adjusting mirrors – designed to make manoeuvring such a large vehicle safer and simpler for drivers 7.Hazard warning lights – which are automatically applied in the event of full brake application 8.Roll Control Assist 9.Stability Control Assist 10.Proximity Control with Stop & Go

item.title: Avis Budget Group maxes out on Mercedes vans with 620 new vehicles
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
The car rental company Avis Budget Group has made a huge investment in Mercedes vans, by placing an order for more than 600 Vito, Sprinter and Viano vans. In total, the Avis Budget Group, which operates in the Southern half of Europe, will take delivery of 620 vans bearing the signature three-pointed Mercedes star. More than 330 models will head to Spain, whilst 250 will operate for Avis in Italy and 35 will serve Portugal. Explaining what such a large number of Mercedes vans will be used for and why Avis picked Mercedes-Benz in the first place, the company’s head of Sales and Marketing in Spain, Italy and Portugal, Ramon Biarnes, said:
“We will deploy our new rental vehicles from Mercedes-Benz Vans at the most important locations in Southern Europe – in particular at airports and large cities,” “The high standard of comfort and reliability of the vans from Mercedes-Benz testifies to our performance orientation at Avis.”
Mercedes-Benz was also thrilled with the repeat business from the Avis Budget Group, with the company’s Klaus Maier recently saying that the large order “attests to our customer orientation and for sure to our vans.”

item.title: Transport firm gets its 100th New Actros
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
Turners, one of the biggest privately-owned transport companies in the UK, has taken delivery of its 100th New Actros truck. The company bought its very first New Actros just over a year ago, and hasn’t looked back ever since. Following a successful trial period with the New Actros, one of the most popular and critically acclaimed of all Mercedes trucks, Turners ordered 58 more units to arrive before Christmas. Since then, more New Actros trucks have been steadily arriving in batches, being added to the company’s 1,100 strong fleet of trucks. Turners has now reached a landmark with its 100th unit, a 6x2 New Actros 2545 tractor unit with a 2.3 wide version of the super-aerodynamic StreamSpace cab. Speaking of the model’s performance, Group Fleet Engineer Tim King commented:
“Our New Actros have been faultless and are now firmly established as the most economical vehicles on the fleet. It’s difficult to quote precise fuel figures because the applications and routes vary so widely, which is why we focus on driving styles. “But when operating at 44 tonnes gcw for most, if not all of the time, these vehicles are consistently returning mpg figures in the high nines and even tens. This puts them at between a third and half a mile per gallon ahead of the 440 hp units from the last Actros range, which had been setting the standard for fuel efficiency.”

item.title: Vito van a mobile advertisement for door business
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded:
When looking for a versatile, hard-working new van for its fleet, a door business based in Huntingdon found the ideal solution in the Mercedes Vito van. David Horne, the co-director of BH Doors & Engineering David, decided to invest in the Mercedes Vito 116 CDI Sport because of its incredible versatility. As it is a Dualiner Compact model, it can carry both goods and passengers. Mr Horne, whose new van is racked out for all his tools and equipment but also has a second row of seats to transport passengers comfortably and safely, explained:
“The Vito Sport is really two vehicles in one,” “It’s a practical, fuel-efficient van while I’m working, but doubles as a stylish and comfortable private car for the evenings and weekends.”
The Vito Sport is also the perfect advertisement for BH Doors & Engineering itself, which specialises in installing, maintaining and repairing doors, including fire doors and moveable walls, throughout southern and central England. The van has dynamic good looks, glossy black paintwork, a personalised registration plate, chrome sidebars and 17 inch six-spoke alloy wheels, and also bears the livery of the company.

item.title: EEG invests in fleet of Mercedes Sprinter vans
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The drain maintenance specialist EEG, a company based in Glasgow, has added no less than 17 new Mercedes Sprinter vans to its fleet. EEG already runs Mercedes Sprinter vans and has enjoyed their reliability and fuel efficiency for many years, so turning to the Sprinter once more when a fleet of new 5.0-tonne vans was needed was an easy decision. Fleet manager Douglas Stewart said:
"These vehicles represent a new venture for us. But we already run around 50 Sprinter vans with CCTV equipment, which we use to inspect drains. "We've been relying on Sprinters since 2002 and although they rack up some very high mileages, only very rarely does one suffer a problem. You can't buy that sort of reliability anywhere other than Mercedes-Benz."
The 17 new Sprinter 513 CDI vans, which have been ordered in the chassis cab variant, have been fitted with specialist equipment including a water tank, jetting and suction tools. The new vans will be joining EEG’s existing fleet of 300 trucks, which include Mercedes trucks in their number. The Sprinter vans, which are much more compact and manageable than large truck units, are needed for jobs and areas where trucks are too large to gain access.

item.title: New survey reveals fleet managers’ top priorities for coming year
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A new survey has revealed what fleet managers throughout the UK consider to be their top priorities for the next year. The results of the study, which was carried out by the fleet management and contract hire specialist Grosvenor Contracts, show that fleet operators are focusing on: •Accident management – with 50 per cent naming this as a top priority •Short-term lease – 51 per cent of those surveyed said this •Daily rental – 49 per cent named this as a top priority for the next 12 months. The survey was taken amongst managers and decision makers in more than 100 fleets, including those that run Mercedes vans and trucks. It involved asking operators to rate the importance of the key services which support their principal contract hire. Commenting on the survey results, the managing director of Grosvenor Contracts, Shaun Barritt, said:
“There’s a sense of cautious optimism as we see economic conditions improving,” “However, no-one wants to over commit which is why the use of short-term lease and daily rental is so popular, because both services give fleet operators flexibility and enable them to keep their options open. “Accident management has always been seen as important, simply because accident costs can be so expensive and the process of handling any incident very time consuming. For this reason, it’s always been a service we’ve seen high demand for.”

item.title: Sprinter vans help Iceland Foods roll out online shopping service
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
Although it is a little behind other retailers in allowing customers to do their grocery shopping from the comfort of their own homes, Iceland Foods has now announced that it is rolling out an online shopping service.
The frozen foods chain has also revealed that it would not be able to offer such a service without its sparkling new fleet of vehicles, which consists entirely of brand new Mercedes Sprinter vans. Having struck up a great five-year deal with its local dealer, Iceland Foods has now replaced its entire fleet with reliable, hardworking and super-efficient Mercedes Sprinter vans.
A total of 1,300 Sprinters will now set out on the roads as the company’s home delivery fleet, delivering customer orders to homes throughout certain parts of the UK. Each vehicle is presumably fitted out with freezer compartments and cold storage facilities to enable orders to stay frozen throughout their journey from store to doorstep.
For now, Iceland Foods is only trialling the scheme in stores in the North East, North West, South West and London. If the service and the Sprinters work out, the service will hopefully be rolled out to the whole of the UK.

item.title: The Mercedes Vario – essentially two vehicles in one
item.dc:creator: kerry
item.content:encoded: Not every van suits every application or every commercial need, which is why each model in the Mercedes vans family can be customised. Customers can choose from different lengths, body types, engines and even extra equipment, to essentially custom build the vehicle they need. However, there is also a Mercedes van that has been specially designed to meet a wide range of varying customer needs. The Mercedes Vario van is essentially two vehicles in one, as it has all the advantages of a van whilst also performing some of the tasks of a light duty truck. In fact, Mercedes even calls it “a truck among vans”. So, if you need a vehicle that is compact enough to access tight spaces or to get loads or passengers from A to B in a busy city, but you also need to carry heavy loads for long distances, the Vario is the ideal choice. Applications of the Vario The Mercedes Vario, like other Mercedes vans, can also be customised, opening it up to an even wider range of different applications. With a little special attention, the basic model can be transformed into anything from a fire and rescue vehicle or an ambulance to a mini bus, construction site vehicle or a small truck for transporting goods long distances.

item.title: The time is right for Aberdeen haulier to return to Mercedes trucks
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
A whole thirty years after the company last ran a Mercedes truck, Aberdeen-based haulier William Walker Transport has made the decision to return to Mercedes-Benz. Explaining why the haulage specialist has chosen now to invest in a brand new Mercedes New Actros truck, joint owner Jim Walker said:
"We've been hearing and reading a lot of good reports about the fuel-efficiency of the New Actros, so we decided the time was right to take a look,"
Mr Walker also mentioned that the New Actros was the best value vehicle available, even though it wasn’t the cheapest to buy outright. He said:
“We like to run our trucks for at least 10 years, so fuel efficiency and whole life running costs are more important to us than the up-front price. It was on this basis that we decided to give the Mercedes-Benz a try,"
After running a demonstration vehicle and finding that the New Actros could deliver fuel efficiency figures of over 8mpg, William Walker Transport decided to go ahead and purchase a unit. After taking delivery of its New Actros 2545 model with a StreamSpace cab and 450bhp straight-six engine (mated to Mercedes PowerShift 3 automated transmission), the company is now anticipating significant savings in fuel costs over the next few years.

item.title: Vito Sport X joins Multi Distribution fleet alongside Sprinter and Atego
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
Multi Distribution, a distribution specialist based in Croydon, Hemel Hempstead and Oxford, has a brand new addition to its fleet of Mercedes vans and trucks. The family-run company has purchased a Mercedes Vito van, with another two on order. Wanting a vehicle with a little more personality than other compact vans, managing director Zamir Raja went for the Vito Sport X, which has a 224bhp V6 engine and in this case, has been ordered with a stunning bright purple body wrap. Explaining why he plumped for the Vito Sport X over other Mercedes vans, Zamir said:
"I just love the Vito Sport-X," "It's a vehicle that appeals to the heart as well as the head by being roomy and practical, yet at the same time beautiful. Plus, of course, it's fast and great fun to drive,"
The model will now join the other Mercedes trucks and vans in the Multi Distribution fleet, which include two Mercedes Atego trucks and two Mercedes Sprinter vans. The 7.5 tonne Ategos are fitted with Dhollandia tail lift equipment, whilst the 3.5 tonne Sprinters are 313 CDI models, amongst the most popular in the Sprinter family.

item.title: Gloucestershire haulier makes savings with the New Actros
item.dc:creator: karen
item.content:encoded:
T Barry, a haulage specialist in Gloucestershire, has only been running its Mercedes New Actros trucks for ten weeks, but the company is already seeing incredible fuel efficiency returns. The company first purchased a new Mercedes Actros 2551 model with a 510hp engine, and it managed to return 6.97mpg after just ten weeks of service. This was impressive, especially considering that the fleet average is 6.4mpg. The next purchase for T Barry six weeks later was a Mercedes 2542 New Actros with a 420hp engine, and this unit is now averaging 6.91mpg. Expressing his delight in the new additions to the T Barry fleet, the company’s managing director Bob Barry said:
“Bulk haulage will never be the most fuel-efficient of applications, so a saving of half a mile per gallon is worth a great deal,” “In fact, it equates to about £4,600 a year for a single vehicle. Multiply that by the 20 tractors on our fleet and you’re talking about £92,000 – that sort of figure can make all the difference to our bottom line.” “We’re very pleased with our latest Mercedes-Benz trucks and particularly the New Actros, which look great and have been a big hit with the drivers.”

item.title: Vito taxis help launch cocktail competition in Edinburgh
item.dc:creator: tony
item.content:encoded:
In conjunction with a seller of premium spirits and a taxi advertising company, a fleet of Mercedes Vito vans helped launch a major cocktail competition in Edinburgh. The Vito vans, which are most commonly used as black taxis in big cities such as London as well as Edinburgh, have been recruited by Hi-Spirits as part of Buffalo Trace Distillery’s taxi campaign to raise awareness of the Edinburgh Festival Cocktail Competition. The Vito taxis were branded with the spirit company’s brand messages, including showcase material for its award-winning whiskeys, and promotional messages for the barrel ageing cocktail competition which took place in high end bars across Aberdeen and Glasgow as well as Edinburgh. Also included in the branding materials on the taxis were messages supporting the 'The Thinking Drinkers Guide to Alcohol', which the Distillery is sponsoring. Speaking of the three-month campaign and the Mercedes Vito van’s vital role in it, the managing director of Hi-Spirits, Dan Bolton, said:
“Along with our sponsorship of 'The Thinking Drinker's Guide to Alcohol' at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, our barrel ageing cocktail competition also promotes key aspects of Edinburgh's cultural life. Splashing our brand messages across the city's dominant Vito black taxis delivers excellent exposure to an audience who are enjoying the delights of this beautiful city."

item.title: The Rise of the Used Van
item.dc:creator: emily
item.content:encoded:
The demand for good quality used vans continues to surge, consistently outstripping supply and forcing the prices of vehicles up. Some figures suggest prices for used vans have risen by 3% between August and September in 2013 alone. That makes it all the more important to choose the right van for your needs and make sure you’re getting value for money. Here are the most popular types of used van that tend to be purchased for commercial use:

  • Tipper

Designed for moving aggregate, tipper trucks feature a hydraulic-controlled flatbed that can be tipped to quickly empty the load at your destination. The 1.45 tonne payload and relatively small size (tippers are typically just 3 metres long) make them a good choice for urban driving and operations. A new tipper truck costs around £28,000, whilst you should expect to pay £8000 for a used model in good condition.

  • Panel Van

When you need a good all-rounder that can carry and protect your tools and provide a mobile base to operate from, the panel van is an ideal commercial vehicle. Small enough to drive and park in cities (a panel van is up to 4.1 metres long), but with the comfort and resilience to travel, the panel van should easily accommodate three passengers and up to 1.5 tonnes of equipment. A new panel van costs from £18,000, whilst a well-maintained used unit will set you back £8,000.

  • Luton Van

When a panel van is just too small, but a curtainside van is too big, the Luton van is the perfect fit. Despite being just 4 metres long, the Luton van carries up 1.6 tonnes and provides the space you need to carry just about anything, anywhere and still with enough room for a three man team. A new Luton van typically costs around £20,000, whilst a used model can cost up to £19,000.

  • Dropside Van

Dropside vans are built around a flat-bed chassis with fold-down surrounds. Measuring up to 4.75 metres in length, and with a 5 tonne capacity, dropside vans are flexible enough to carry almost any cargo, including aggregate, large tools and other heavy equipment. Expect to pay around £18,000 for a new dropside van, or £11,000+ for a good value used model.

  • Curtainside Van

For heavy duty applications where capacity and load are critical, nothing beats a curtainside van. You will be able to carry up to 18 tonnes across country with ease, backed by up to three passengers. The curtain sides fold back, allowing for easy loading and unloading of pallets, crates and other cargo. New, a curtainside van costs from £20,000 (depending on size), and a good quality used model can cost up to £18,000.

Thinking about buying a used van?

Trevor Siederer, Used Sales Manager, advises coming to a swift decision if you’re keen to buy a used van: “Used van prices continue to rise month on month, suggesting that buyers need to act sooner rather than later or face being priced out of the market,” he said. “With so many different van types available, there is something to suit every budget and application, but with prices continuing to increase, second hand buyers may find themselves with fewer choices, being forced to settle for an older, less well-maintained alternative.”
